description:
Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn, Artist and filmmaker Brit Bunkley discusses the pragmatics and politics of making art with AI. Join us for a discussion in the Gallery, with insights into the making of his latest work Archive, commissioned for Messengers.
--
Brit Bunkley is a New Zealand-based artist and videographer whose practice spans sculpture, installation, and digital media. A recipient of the US National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, two NY state grants, and the Rome Prize Fellowship, his work explores the intersection of physical and virtual spaces, often blending surreal imagery with themes of history, politics, and environmental concerns. He has exhibited at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa and internationally at Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, FILE São Paulo (including 2025), and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. Recent exhibitions include Visions in the Nunnery, London (2022), Cybersculpture 2024 at Collège des Bernardins, Paris, and The Torrance Art Museum, LA (2025). In 2024, he won Best Art | Experimental Video/Film at the New York City Independent Film Festival. His work continues to evolve, embracing new technologies and alternative methodologies to challenge perceptions of reality and imagination.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Ask the Astronomer - Running Every 90 Mins, ASK THE ASTRONOMER
Richard Hall or another astronomer will be available to answer questions on specific topics. Topics for the day will be advertised on the day. Come along and find out the answers to those questions you were curious about. Whenever possible, sessions will run every 90mins throughout the day. Just come for a self-guided tour and the session is free.

The theme of Carterton Space Week is the Dark Sky. careers in space but our sessions will not be confined to that. We find lots of space ideas really interesting.

The astronomer will introduce the topic then you ask the questions. No restrictions on age.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Author Talk: Oceans Between Us ed. by Sereana Naepi, We're delighted to have Sereana Naepi in the shop to talk about Oceans Between Us: Pacific Peoples & Racism in Aotearoa, which she edited and was published by Auckland University Press.
Oceans Between Us is both a testimony and a call to action. It documents the struggles of Pacific peoples and envisions a world beyond now. A rallying cry for justice, a demand for equity and a catalyst for change, this book is not about survival alone – it’s about thriving.
All welcome!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Avalanche Safety Talk, What do pizza and avalanches have in common..? They are both on the agenda for our next section night!
Next week, we have our Avalanche Awareness Talk.
Whether you are a skier, boarder, climber or hunter we hope this evening inspires you to refresh or start building your avalanche knowledge and rescue skills so you are able to enjoy our beautiful backcountry safely.
We encourage you to invite others that you know that frequent the alpine regions too as the information presented is an essential part of safe travel.
There'll be pizza and a chance to mingle with other keen adventurers
we look forward to seeing you there!

Photo Credit: Peter Laurenson
label: Community & Culture

description:
BUTTERCAT X PŌNEKE NGERU FLASH DAY, BUTTERCAT x PŌNEKE NGERU CHARITY FLASH DAY
To celebrate Buttercat Tattoo Studios new space they will be hosting a fundraiser flash day for Pōneke Ngeru Rescue Trust
Pōneke Ngeru Rescue is a foster-based cat charity in Wellington. We rescue, rehabilitate, and rehome cats from surrendered pets to wild colony cats. Our mahi includes vet visits, trapping, microchip checks, advocating for responsible ownership, promoting desexing and microchipping, and caring for a managed colony of 40 wild cats in Berhampore.
50% of the cost of your tattoo will be donated. We will have prizes and goodies available as well as special guest artists!
Doors open at 11am

Tattoos are cash only
To be kept up to date with more details please follow @buttercattattoo & @ponekengerurescue on instagram
label: Community & Culture

description:
Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson), Please note: the event is free but it can only continue if we support the Southern Cross by buying food or drinks

Wellington’s favourite monthly Bachata Latin dance party

Join us for an awesome mix of bachata, focusing on the best sensual tracks and remixes, along with salsa and a smattering of kizomba and zouk. We welcome everyone, from the absolute beginner to the most experienced dancer. We’re all about the joy of social dancing together.
And what makes a free party with great people even better? A free beginners’ bachata lesson with some of Wellington‘s best Latin dance teachers. If you’ve never danced bachata, Latin dance or even any other dance style before then this is the perfect lesson for you. We will have you dancing like a pro in no time!
Bailamos Bachata is hosted free of charge by the Southern Cross. They love the atmosphere we bring but we also need to support them in return. We’re asking everyone attending to purchase soft drinks, food or alcohol from the bar. It’s vital we show our gratitude.
1800-1830 social
1830-1900 free lesson
1900-2100 social
Q&A
Q. What is bachata?
A. Bachata is a popular and fun Latin couples dance. It started in the Dominican Republic, then travelled to Europe and the rest of the world. It now includes a wide range of music styles and dance influences and is still changing and evolving.
Q. I haven’t danced before, is that a problem?
A. Not at all! That’s exactly what the lesson is for – everyone has to start somewhere and we’re a very welcoming crowd for beginners.
Q. Is bachata a difficult dance to learn?
A. Its origins as a party/community dance mean the basics can be learnt quite quickly, so you’ll be enjoying yourself in no time.
Q. Who are the capital bachata collective?
A. We are the combined Wellington dance schools and people teaching bachata and we really want to share this dance with everyone. We love bachata, we love our community and we want to share it with you
￼

description:
Benefit Show For Displaced Children Of Gaza And Ukraine, So, unless you've been living up in the mountains for the past few years, you may have heard there's a few wars happening.

In the past few years, thousands of children been forced by conflict to flee their home countries & seek safety in refugee camps around the world. But many of these camps lack basics like food and water, they also lack resources necessary to continue the children's education like books, I pads and laptops.

So four Wellington bands have united to raise money for these children.

LUNG
S H E
Electric Tapestry
Antu Marama

Newtown Community center on the corner of Colombo Street &, Rintoul Street

$15 online or $20 on the door
All profits will be donated directly to refugee camps for the displaced children of Gaza and Ukraine.
Come down listen to some sick bands and support children in need.

No Alcohol no drugs and be a dick

You can read more about the causes we are supporting here
https://ucap.help/projects/
https://www.pcrf.net/refugee-food-aid

Stay Sick and see you there

description:
CFs 20th Birthday Celebrations, On the 10th of October 2005 Rafael Ferrer Noel arrived in New Zealand and CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists - was born.
Coincidentally the 10th of October is also Cuban Independence Day (a.k.a. El Dia del Grito de Yara) - on this day in 1868, Carlos Manuel de Céspedes, "Father of the Homeland", gave freedom to his slaves and started the independence war against the Spanish colonial power, which led to the Ten Years' War
So we've got lots to celebrate and commemorate today!
A BIG GRACIAS to our teachers and assistants present and past (Rogelio Enrique Carles-Rosas, Nina Baranenko, Niki Boolieris and Jenny Beech), and all our students, dancers and supporters over the years. Without you we would not exist!
label: Community & Culture

description:
CHAPPELL vs CHARLI: A DRAG FUNDRAISER SMACKDOWN, Saturday 27 September | 9.30pm @ Ivy Bar, Pōneke
Tickets: $20 (excluding ticket fees) | Generosity options available!
All proceeds to Wellington Pride Festival!
Kia ora brats and popstars! Get your heads out the passenger seat and get ready, cause your about to be bumpin’ that with some of wellington drags finest!
Royalty is stepping into the ring (well, the stage) for CHAPPELL vs CHARLI : a high-camp, high-stakes, drag smackdown showdown, where our fabulous local drag artists channel the icons of Charli XCX and Chappell Roan to battle it out for title of 'Queen of the Chartsverse'… all in the name of charity xx
THE SMACKDOWN

Three lip sync rounds. Four drag titans. One glitter-drenched champion.
Each round sees performers pull a mystery song each from their assigned diva’s discography and fight for the crown based on lip sync accuracy and undeniable star quality. Think charity boxing... but queerer. Like, much queerer. Only you! The audience... and our incredible judge Rachel Winter Hase can determine our number #1 pop icon!
FEATURING
Homer Neurotic (multi-award-winning drag king)
Slay West (the biggest mouth in the biz)
Petra Fyde (now your petrified)
Ms. Leading (Your big bros lil secret)
(and Olivia Dreams on door)
Hosted by the ever-glamorous Selina Simone, and judged by local performance legend Rachel Winter Hase, who will deliver her pop verdicts with love and lashes *whipcrack.mp3
A high-speed crash of glitter, vocals, and vengeance! Expect drag, drama, and come ready to holler, hoot, bump, and help us decide who is our ultimate XCX BRAT or CHAPPELL POPSTAR!
Tickets: Just $20 + fees, with donation options for those feeling generous – every cent raised goes to support Wellington Pride Festival, helping make 2025 the queerest yet!
ACCESSIBILITY: Ivy Bar is located downstairs but alternative access is possible with prior planning. Please email theselinasimone@gmail.com so we can accommodate you. If you wish to attend and donate, but cost is an issue for you, please reach to me as well
Heels on, lashes locked… it’s time to throw down (glamorously). CHAPPELL vs CHARLI is not a drill. See you under the spotlight, darling xx
label: Community & Culture

description:
CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.
***
PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK
LA VITA IN ROSA
LEVEN IN ROZE
LA VIDA EN ROSA
LA VIE EN ROSE
ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO
AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.
***
CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.
What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.
Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!
Dress Code: PINK!
Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!
Suggested Koha/Donation: $5
Aiming to fund-raise $1,000 this year.. that's only 200 people @ $5 dancing Salsa in Cuba Street all PINKed up. We can do it!
EFTPOS available - 1.1% surcharge applies.
Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:
02-0343-0003801-007
ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.
Please give generously.
LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.
NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.
RAIN DATE: TBC
***
This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.
#because_we_need_a_cure_not_a_miracle
#dontwalkby
#takeaction
#donate
#dancesalsa
#wearpink
#keepcalmdancecuban
Today 8 women will be diagnosed with Breast Cancer
Yet 30% of eligible women are not enrolled for free screening
This year 600+ will most likely die from Breast Cancer
And 60% of women do not know the signs beyond a lump
Knowledge is power… and knowledge helps beat breast cancer. Get knowledgeable here: https://www.breastcancerfoundation.org.nz/breast-awareness
Remember if you are 45-69 and not enrolled for free mammograms you can enrol by calling BreastScreen Aotearoa on 0800 270 200.
To find out more about CUBAN☆FUSION, its dance classes and upcoming dance and music event please visit our website.
CUBAN☆FUSION © 2005 - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists | www.cubanfusion.co.nz | info@cubanfusion.co.nz | 021-621-245

description: Care, anarchy, and mutual aid,  Care, anarchy, and mutual aid: responses to crisis and disaster by the community, for the community  (a community proposed event) We will walk through tangible examples from Monica's experiences of mutual aid organizing for different crisis contexts in Chicago (USA), dispelling disaster myths, what anarchist approaches to community care look like, and brainstorming around what we can do together around what we face as community members in Te Whanganui-a-Tara.  Zines and kai will be shared.

description:
Cohousing in Wellington? Let’s Make It Happen, Circle Living is creating a new story for housing in Aotearoa - building intergenerational cohousing neighbourhoods where people can live more connected lives.
After successfully completing a 34-home cohousing neighbourhood in Tākaka, we’re now exploring the option of bringing cohousing to Wellington. We’d love for you to be part of the conversation.
Join us for an evening of ideas, connection, and opportunity.
📅 Tuesday 7 October 2025
🕠 5:30pm – 6:30pm
📍Creative HQ, Level 1, 7 Dixon Street, Wellington
Tickets are FREE but please sign up as it helps with planning. Nibbles and drinks provided.
✨ Learn about Circle Living and our vision for future cohousing neighbourhoods
✨ Hear what makes cohousing different (and why it matters)
✨ Explore how a Wellington development could look - and register your interest
✨ Find out about our equity crowdfunding campaign via PledgeMe and how you can own a share in our company
✨ Meet others who are curious about living - and investing - differently
Register now and help shape what’s possible with Circle Living.

description:
Community Evening Tri 2, Ignite Consultants is a student-run charitable organisation that provides free and creative advice to charities and social organisations across Aotearoa. All of our consultants are passionate and talented student-volunteers who are driven by their desire to foster social change. Our vision is to help organisations to maximise their impact through harnessing the fresh perspectives of university students.
We run two project cycles per year which coincide with the university semesters, each lasting for a duration of 9 weeks. Each team consists of a local charity, 5-6 students, a project manager (a person who has been through the Ignite Consultants experience before) and a professional mentor who has experience in consulting and/or the industry the organisation works in.

Ignite's Community Evening is a special occasion where our consultants share what they have learnt, created and experienced over the past nine weeks. This event is an opportunity to learn about the remarkable charities we have collaborated with this semester, to enjoy delicious food and to extend our heartfelt thanks to all our supporters.
This semester, attendees will get to hear presentations from the teams who have worked with WELLfed, Take10, Orange Sky, PACE and The Charitable Recycling Trust.

description:
Crime and Punishment, Meeting place is the Bolton Street Cemetery Museum.

Hear stories about the jailers, judges and policemen who were dealing with the city's criminals, as well as some of the villains and murderers that shocked earlier generations in Wellington.


Find out about the duelling pistol that was involved in the deaths of a lawyer and a magistrate; and about an unsolved murder on a quiet farm road. There’s several lawyers, but even a criminal or two.

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/

Eastside Community Emergency Response Practice, A Community Emergency Hub is a place for the community to gather and coordinate efforts to help each other during and after a disaster.

Have fun meeting together and practicing various roles with an interactive earthquake scenario.

Open to all ages and abilities, no experience needed!

Kai will be provided.

For more information, please email info@wremo.nz

We aim to make our community events inclusive to all people. If you are attending the event and have specific accessibility requirements, you can send us an email at info@wremo.nz with the event name and we will get in touch to see how we can meet your needs as best we can.

description:
Echoes of Home - A Musical Journey Across Time, (Ticket Required)
Tuesday , 2 September 2025
Doors open: 4:30 PM | Performance begins: 5:15 PM sharp
Hunter Council Chamber, Hunter Building, Kelburn Parade, Wellington
Free Entry | All Welcome
In celebration of 80 years of Vietnam’s National Day (2/9), join us for a powerful evening of music, memory, and connection.
Through traditional and contemporary Vietnamese songs, Echoes of Home takes you on a heartfelt journey — honouring the past, embracing the present, and looking to the future. Performed by a diverse group of community members, this special event celebrates identity, culture, and the spirit of resilience.
What to expect:
• A beautifully curated musical programme honouring Vietnam’s story
• Performances of folk and modern Vietnamese music
• Dance, piano, harp, pipa, guitar, and more
• Multilingual storytelling to connect all audiences
• A welcoming, cross-cultural experience for all backgrounds
Please note: Doors close at 5:15 PM for the stage programme. No entry will be permitted during performances.
With thanks to our generous supporters:
MAY Coffee Crew • Hell Pizza • First National Real Estate Collective • Bellagio Cafe & Spa • Fabulash Brows & Beauty • Hutt City FM • Hi Tea • Golden Pine Trading Ltd • Saigon Xin Chao • Hutt City FM 106.7!
Hosted by Viet Hub NZ — rooted in culture, powered by community.
Follow this page for more updates
label: Community & Culture

description:
Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time, Event Information
Some days remind us who we are and where we come from — when an entire nation moves as one to honour Independence.
To celebrate the 80th Anniversary of Vietnam’s National Day (2 September), Viet Hub NZ proudly presents
“Echoes of Home – A Musical Across Time”
This free concert is a heartfelt journey through the sounds of Vietnamese history — from nostalgic childhood songs to powerful wartime ballads and modern melodies of pride and hope. All performances will include English subtitles, making it easy for everyone to follow along and connect with the stories.
Whether you’re Vietnamese or simply curious about a different culture, this is a wonderful opportunity to experience the warmth, resilience, and beauty of Vietnam through music and storytelling.
🎁 Raffle with Over $300 in Prizes
Don’t miss our special raffle on the day. Tickets will be available at the venue for $5 and $10. Payment can be made in cash or by bank transfer.
💛 Support Viet Hub NZ
This event is free to attend, but if you believe in what we do and want to help us continue running community workshops, cultural events, and youth-led initiatives — please consider making a donation.
👉 Donate here: https://givealittle.co.nz/cause/viet-hub-nz-rooted-in-culture-powered-by-community
Your koha helps keep our work going, rooted in culture, powered by community.

description:
Father's Day Quiz, Put your general knowledge to the test while supporting a great cause at the Father's Day Quiz!
Join us for a belated celebration of the fathers and father figures in our lives. We welcome everyone to join us, including students and mothers, so make sure to get everyone a ticket.

Date: Monday 8 September
Time: 6:30pm-9pm
Cost: $25 per person, which includes a pizza dinner and a drink
Please bring gold coins for some exciting games to be played throughout the evening.
Click the link to get your tickets now!


This event is part of the 2025 Middle School Challenge fundraiser for Blind Low Vision NZ. Our Middle School Leaders have the unique opportunity to sponsor the development and training of a Guide Dog named Cooper, which costs about $25,000. Your generous donations are greatly appreciated and make a significant difference. Once Cooper is fully trained, he will be placed with a visually impaired person for the rest of his working life. We believe that as the Scots Community bands together, your support can change a life.
To learn more or to make a donation, visit our Givealittle page:

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Our Fair Ladies (April 2025), Our Fair Ladies Tour
Embark on a captivating journey through the history buried in Karori Cemetery with our tour showcasing the remarkable lives of Wellington's women.
This tour offers a unique opportunity to celebrate the resilience, creativity and empowerment of women at a time when a woman couldn't have a bank account in her own name.  You'll hear the stories of women who had a range of interesting occupations. 
Be inspired by the incredible impact of these women's lives in early Wellington.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page.

Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We will meet before the tour at the Shelter (listed as Historic chapel on the map)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery: More Catholic Tales (Nov 2025), Further Catholic Tales - new tour
Hear about a poet, a writer, soldiers and stories of Wellington history. Further Catholic Tales tells the stories of the wide range of people interred in the section known as Catholic 2.
The tour duration is 1 hour 30mins. The tour mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness.

Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday, From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday
Marking 250 years since Austen’s birth this romp through her irreverent Juvenilia is spliced with deliciously pompous gems from Aotearoa’s earliest newspapers.

From the drawing rooms of Georgian England to the dusty streets of Victorian Wellington – the pretensions of polite society never change.

To mark 250 years since the birth of Jane Austen, her wildly funny Juvenilia is brought to life, including The Beautifull Cassandra, The History of England, Love and Friendship – and more.

Between Austen’s sharpest barbs you’ll hear genuine gems from New Zealand’s early newspapers, courtesy of Papers Past: gossip, pomposity, early etiquette advice, and scandalous society mishaps.

The result? A sparkling, one hour romp proving that the absurdities of status, marriage and manners travel across oceans, continents and centuries.

Performed as a series of readings with lightning character swaps, sly narration, and just a hint of scandal, this is Austen as you’ve never heard her: young, bold, and perfectly at home in 19th century Wellington!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $25
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/from-pemberley-to-pipitea-celebrating-jane-austens-250th-birthday/


Health & Safety
Please contact the event host for health & safety information.

description:
Funkin’ Donuts Vinyl Session at Parrotdog Bar, Funkin’ Donuts Vinyl Session at Parrotdog Bar
FLEX WEBSTER + DJ AUDIT [AK]
7" 45 SESSION
ALL STYLES, ALL SMILES
SAT 27 SEPT 2-10PM

FUNKIN’ DONUTS is a celebration of all things funky on the 7” 45 vinyl format.

The brand’s name comes from the records themselves - small, round, and with a large hole in the middle, they’ve long been nicknamed “donuts.”

Founded by Flex Webster in 2022, FUNKIN’ DONUTS began as a jam session with fellow 45 heads before evolving into a platform for original edits and future vinyl releases. With an ultimate vision of putting out 7” records, Flex has already released six albums of party edits under the brand, with plans for the first physical release coming soon. 👀

description:
Gallows Tour - FULLY BOOKED, Gallows Tour - FULLY BOOKED
This event is FULLY BOOKED.


Crime, Justice, and the Final Walk.
Delve into the complex history of capital punishment in Wellington with this thought-provoking tour through Karori Cemetery

Gallows shines a light on the people behind the process. Discover their roles in shaping justice, the cases that defined their careers, and the human stories behind a system of ultimate consequence.

If tickets are sold out, you can join the waitlist here: https://events.humanitix.com/friends-of-karori-cemetery-gallows-tour


Cost: $10
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/gallows-tour/


Health & Safety:
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.

Please dress appropriately for the conditions.

While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.

Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
George Pain: Grocer, Gentleman, Generous Benefactor, George Pain: Grocer, Gentleman, Generous Benefactor
George Pain (1846-1937) merchant, farmer, business owner and philanthropist comes to life to tell us his story in his own words.

An animation of George Pain is the centrepiece of an exhibition recognising his significant contribution to the early growth of Martinborough. His name lives on in the Pain and Kershaw Supermarket but the man himself has become a footnote to history. This exhibition gives him the place he deserves in local history.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/george-pain-grocer-gentleman-generous-benefactor/



Health & Safety:
The spaces in the museum building are small so wheelchair access is very limited.

There are no toilets at the museum. Public toilets are available next door.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival), Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival)
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 2 NOV

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 2 November 2025

Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street

Ends: Vivian Street

Duration: 90 minutes

Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee

This tour is part of the amazing Wellington Heritage Festival - https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz
label: Community & Culture

description:
Heartland Flyer, Heartland Flyer
Travel with Steam Incorporated north from Kapiti via the spectacular Manawatu Gorge to Woodville for an easy day out. Picking up along the way from Paekakariki, Paraparaumu, Waikanae, Otaki, and Levin, our destination today is Woodville. To get there, we travel through the famous Manawatu Gorge. Now only accessible via rail, you get a unique perspective of the monumental slips which closed the Gorge to road traffic from 2017.

At Woodville, sample the delights of the restored 1960s era station whilst our train is prepared for the run back down the coast. Meridian’s Te Apiti wind farm can also be seen from the station, occupying 1,150ha of land, with enough sustainable renewable energy to power 45,000 kiwi homes.

Fares
Adult (12+yrs) - $139
Child (3-12yrs) - $89
Infant (0-2yrs) - Free

Tickets available at steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/heartland-flyer/

description:
Helpful tools for searching NZ historical records, Helpful tools for searching NZ historical records
The Wellington Branch of the NZ Society of Genealogists hosts a demonstration of online tools that make searching for your New Zealand families easier.

Luke Howison will demonstrate some of the features of Ancestor Search Helper (ASH), a free NZ genealogy search site, and also its sister-sites Archway-style Collections Search, an unofficial alternative to searching Archives NZ, and also give a tour of the Intentions to Marry Project, which features 40+ years of digitised and transcribed registers of Intentions to Marry from Archives NZ.


Cost: Free
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/helpful-tools-for-searching-nz-historical-records/


Health & Safety:
Health and Safety instructions will be given at the beginning of the talk. In an emergency evacuation, there are two assembly points in the carpark and between the two greens. The exit to be used in the event of an emergency will be the upstairs door leading directly onto the upper carpark. The bowling club hall and buildings are smoke and vape free. The venue maintains health and safety manuals.

This easy one-hour walk will focus on many of the notable specimen trees planted since 1868. The majority of the trees around the duck pond and its surrounds were planted in 1871 and 1872. This is the heart of the Wellington Botanic Garden where all the early plantings were carried out by the first administration.

Meet at the Founders' Entrance, Glenmore Street. Cost: Free.

description:
Heritage Thorndon, Heritage Thorndon
Explore New Zealand oldest suburb on foot.

Journey from first peoples, through church and state, to historic and current residences and business.

Your journey with Walk Wellington commences at Old St Paul's (Murphy Street) and then takes us through the Parliament precinct to Hill Street, and into Tinakori Road. We then loop around Glenbervie Terrace to continue along Tinakori Road to Bowen Street and then back to follow Ascot and Sydney Street West. We finish at Kaiwakatere (the Navigator) behind Parliament and off Bowen Street.

This walk focuses on the period of time from first peoples through the contact period and changes of the early 1800's to the Empire City of the late 1800's.


Booking is REQUIRED.

Cost: Koha

Booking info here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/heritage-thorndon-25/


Health & Safety:
Guide will follow safe pedestrian practices.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY, THIS INVITE IS FOR THE PUKERUA BAY SWAP

Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
3-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
3.15-3.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
3.45-4pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!

description:
Kids Rock 4 Palestine, Kids Rock For Palestine
One Day. One Stage. One Cause.
This event is organised by kids in Pōneke to raise funds for kids in Palestine.
Join us for a one-day-only music fundraiser where young voices take centre stage to amplify hope and raise money for children in Palestine.
Under-18 musicians, solo artists, and bands (some joined by over-18 allies) are coming together to rock out with purpose, showing that music knows no borders and compassion has no age limit.
These young performers are using their talents to stand in solidarity with kids just like them who are living through unimaginable circumstances.
Organiser Eddie 12: "We see children in Palestine who are being bombed and shot and are starving. We kids want to help. So that is what we are doing."
There will be stalls and crafting available for kids attending - Please come and support so we can raise money for Gaza's families.
100% of proceeds go directly to emergency aid and child-focused relief in Palestine - Convoys of Good and Kiwi Trust for Palestinian Childrens Relief.
Witness the next generation of artists and activists sharing the stage and raising their voices. Please support them with your attendance. Show them young people can make a difference.
Be part of an event where music becomes action, and community becomes change.
Do you want to volunteer to help? Email aotearoa2gaza@gmail.com
ALL UNDER 18s MUST ATTEND WITH A PARENT OR GUARDIAN.
Can’t make it? Donate anyway!

description:
Letters out Loud 2025 — Part of Friends of the Turnbull Library Public Programme Series, A 1940 newspaper exhorted its readers to ‘write a letter! Take a little chunk of your heart and spread it over some paper; it goes, oh, such a long way!’
Letters out Loud will expose some of those heart-felt issues people addressed on paper in the past. Well-known personalities will read letters from the Alexander Turnbull Library Collections which reveal concerns, among other things:
* the oldest extant Māori letter, written and read by a child
* the ups and downs of farm life
* Yehudi Menuhin in the bath
* a Member of Parliament in love
* on board the sinking Wahine in 1968.
Brought to life by familiar voices
Letters out Loud will be an evening of historical texts brought to life by familiar voices. Come and enjoy an enlivening of the past that has many resonances for today. Speakers include Ngahiwi Apanui- Barr, Una Cruickshank, Tanea Heke, Michele Leggott, David O’Donnell, Karen O’Leary, Trevor Richards, Vaughan Slinn, and Jennifer Ward-Lealand.
Doors open at 5pm for drinks and nibbles, readings begin at 6pm.
Book your tickets
Tickets to this gala fundraising event include a souvenir programme and refreshments.
https://events.humanitix.com/copy-of-letters-out-loud
All profits go to support grants for research at the Alexander Turnbull Library. The Friends of the Turnbull Library (FOTL) offer grants of $20,000 available to scholars whose research involves the use of the collections of the Alexander Turnbull Library.
https://turnbullfriends.org.nz/research-grant/

Come talk
to some people who've done it!
Every year, a diverse range of New Zealanders representing a variety of backgrounds, ages, interests, and cultures start a life-changing adventure in Japan-and next year that could include you!
With applications for the New Zealand JET Programme around the corner, you may have questions about what it's actually like to be sent off to live and teach in Japan for a year or more!
The JET Alumni Association of Wellington, in coordination with The Embassy of Japan, have organised a casual evening event for prospective applicants to ask those questions, and hear some stories to help you make a better decision about if the JET Programme is right for you.
Q&A event details
Date: 6th October 2025
Time: 17:30 - 19:30
Location: Yoshi Sushi & Bento (Press Hall, Willis Street)
Doors open from 5:30, with Q&A starting from 6:00.
Enjoy free
courtesy of Yoshi Sushi & Bento.
(Drinks, including Japanese
will also be available for purchase).
So come along and bring your friends
to this great opportunity to meet a handful of the thousands of Kiwis who've taken part in this programme over the past 40 years
Anyone interested in applying is welcome to attend!

What is the Japan Exchange Teaching (JET) Programme, you ask?
The JET Programme is an overseas employment opportunity to live and work in Japan for a year or more! You could soon head abroad on the adventure of a lifetime, and get paid for it!
Programme criteria includes the following-are you:
A New Zealand citizen?
Already graduated?
Or will have your Bachelor's Degree/Teaching Diploma conferred by early July 2026?
Interested in international activities?
Interested in teaching English to young people and living in Japan?

Positions available:
Assistant Language Teacher (ALT)
ALTs help the Japanese foreign language teachers in class and help prepare teaching materials and class activities. They may assist in English language clubs and other extra-curricular activities. Knowledge of Japanese is not required to be an ALT.
Coordinator for International Relations (CIR)
CIRs work in local government offices and are involved in international activities, which might include editing publications, translation work, advising on the planning and implementation of exchange programmes, and interpreting at international events. A functional knowledge of written and spoken Japanese is required to be a CIR.
For more information about the New Zealand JET Programme, visit:
https://www.nz.emb-japan.go.jp/itpr_en/jet.html
https://www.facebook.com/JETProgrammeNZ/
We hope to see you there!

8:00pm - Bababear (House)

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.
This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.
Meet the panel:
Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.
Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.
And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.

description:
Mount Street Cemetery Open Day, Mount Street Cemetery Open Day
Mount Street Cemetery is Wellingtons first Catholic cemetery. It has a strong historical connection to early Wellington and is a quiet sanctuary in the city.

Friends of the Mount Street Cemetery will be hosting an open day for people to visit and experience the cemetery. They will be on hand to describe the history of the cemetery, its connections to early settlers and the Catholic community in Wellington, and conservation efforts. A leisurely stroll around the cemetery takes about 1 hour.


Cost: Free

Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/mount-street-cemetery-open-day-25/


Health & Safety:
Visitors are asked to respect the cemetery and keep to paths and tracks. They are advised to look where placing feet so as to avoid tripping over. Please keep away from the steep bank on the boundary with McKenzie Terrace. Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather.

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20

The Sunday 19 October session is fully booked.
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

Neurodivergent Speed Dating 20-35, 35-50, Looking to meet new friends to hang out with, or maybe find love in a comfortable, respectful environment? Join us for a speed dating event designed specifically for autistic adults in Wellington!
This inclusive and sensory-considerate evening is all about meaningful conversations and low-pressure socializing. Whether you’re looking for friendship, romance, or just a fun evening out, this is your chance to connect in a space designed with your needs in mind.
Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!
Accessibility and Comfort:
We’re committed to making this event as accessible and welcoming as possible. Sensory-friendly spaces, quiet zones, and fidget-friendly items will be available. There will also be conversation prompts on the table. Let us know any additional accommodations you may need when registering.
Who Can Attend:
All genders and sexualities are welcome to come and mingle and meet others for friendship but the speed dating part of this evening works best for heterosexual people.

description:
New Zealand Game Developers Conference, This is more than just a conference; it’s a celebration of Aotearoa’s amazing game dev community.
Our theme for this year is The People at the Heart of Games and is inspired by the well-known Māori proverb “He aha te mea nui o te ao? He tangata, he tangata, he tangata” (What is the most important thing in the world? It is people, it is people, it is people), emphasising the human side of game development.
It speaks to the importance of community, collaboration and the people who shape our industry - developers, storytellers, players, and cultural guardians.
We’ll have inspiring talks, engaging workshops, and vibrant panel discussions that highlight voices from all corners of our industry.
Whether you’re a veteran developer, an enthusiastic gamer, or just starting your journey, NZGDC 2025 is the perfect place to forge new friendships, exchange ideas, and ignite your creativity!

description:
Our Fair Ladies, Our Fair Ladies
Embark on a journey through the history buried in Karori Cemetery with our tour showcasing the remarkable lives of Wellington’s women.

This tour offers a unique opportunity to celebrate the resilience, creativity and empowerment of women at a time when a woman couldn’t have a bank account in her own name. You’ll hear the stories of women who had a range of interesting occupations.

Be inspired by the incredible impact of these women’s lives in early Wellington.


Booking is REQUIRED.

Cost: $10

Booking info here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/our-fair-ladies-tour/


Health & Safety:
Please dress appropriately for the conditions.

While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.

Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:

Our Whare Our Fale Information Session!

The session provides you with more detail on what owning an Our Whare Our Fale home means and what the process will be so you can decide whether an Our Whare Our Fale home will work for you and your family.

At the end of the session you will be given the opportunity to sign a Participation Agreement and from this point we will start the journey with you and your family towards home ownership.

If you haven't yet expressed your interest into the Our Whare Our Fale programme, you can do so here: centralpacificcollective.my.site.com/s/eoi

We would love to see you there!

description:
Over the Rainbow, Over the Rainbow
There’s no place like Pōneke.

Queer historian Will Hansen and legendary barman Malcolm Vaughan kōrero the capital’s vibrant LGBTQIA+ nightlife for Wellington Heritage Festival.


About Will

Will Hansen (he/him) is a transgender historian based in Pōneke. He is the recipient of a Judith Binney Trust Writing Award and is currently working on turning his PhD thesis – ‘Queer Activism in Aotearoa, 1961-2013’ into a book. Will is also a trustee of Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa.


About Mal

Malcolm Vaughan is a Wellington gay icon. Before the Homosexual Law Reform Act of 1986, Mal worked at a series of bars and late-night haunts in the capital. More than just places to drink, venues like The Dominion, Bamboo Bar, Casper’s, The Dome (to name a few) provided a safe place in the capital for the city’s rainbow community to meet without prejudice. Today, Malcolm alongside husband, Scotty Kennedy ow and run the iconic Cuba Street establishment Scotty & Mal’s Cocktail and Lounge Bar.

Advocates for many LGBTQIA+ causes, they have supported many community initiatives over the years. In 2000 they co-founded the After Life Memorial Trust, now called the Chrissy Wītoko Memorial Trust, which originally provided financial support for AIDS patients of the rainbow community. The Trust continues to provide a wide range of support for the Wellington rainbow community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm

Dogs go FREE

description:
Pipe Band Centenary Dinner, Join us as we celebrate 100 years of the Scots College Pipe Band at a Centenary Dinner on 20 September 2025! This milestone event promises to be filled with nostalgia, reconnections, and memories with old and current friends.
There are two parts to this exciting event: the Pipe Band Reunion Rehearsal, and the Pipe Band Centenary Dinner.
Pipe Band Reunion Rehearsal
On 20 September at 2pm, we invite all past and present band members to gather for a get together and a rehearsal. The music that we will rehearse at this session will be played at the Centenary Dinner, and this event will conclude around 4:30pm.
Pipe Band Centenary Dinner
We invite you to our very special Pipe Band Centenary Dinner starting at 7pm in the Scots College Hall, which includes Guest Speaker Sir Ashley Bloomfield, performances by past and present Band members, a Haggis ceremony, and reflections on 100 years of the Pipe Band at Scots College.
We look forward to celebrating this historical moment with you!

description:
Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.
Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.
This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.
Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!
The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.
Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.
The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.
Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book
This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).

description:
Randell Cottage Annual Open Day, Tour this small colonial Cottage and marvel that it once housed a couple and their ten children. Share afternoon tea and listen to authors reading their works.
Randell Cottage is a rare example of colonial domestic architecture and is a listed historic place. It retains most of its original 19th century configuration, although modified as a comfortable home for writers from NZ and France. It is only open to the public annually as part of the Festival. The event includes a series of readings from current and past residents.
A limited programme will be offered if weather conditions are poor.

Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/.../randell.../

description:
Roll For Romance (AGE 25-39), Single? Fancy a game night with a twist?

 

This event takes the classic board game evening and gives it a speed-dating spin. From 7.00 to 9.00 pm, you’ll have the chance to meet up to 20 singles and bond over a carefully selected set of board games picked to spark conversation and laughter.

 

You’ll play in mixed-gendered groups and rotate around to meet different groups. You’ll stay with your same-gendered group throughout the night, so don’t sweat it if you’re a bit shy—bring a friend along for the ride.

 

First drink’s on us, because let’s face it, gaming is thirsty work!

 

After the games wrap up, feel free to hang out with your new acquaintances till 9.15. Or, if you’ve got to run, be sure to fill out one of our match cards, and we’ll connect you with your matches in the coming days.

 

Perfect for singles looking to mix fun with the chance to meet someone special.

 

Recommended age 25-39.

 

Not your jam? Check out our other upcoming events on our website!
By purchasing a ticket you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms & Conditions.

You'll also be close to Old St Pauls, the Anglican Cathedral and Parliament. We can then meet around 12pm at Chapman-Taylors for coffee / lunch. See you there!

description:

This September we're kicking off Skyline Singles!

No time limit, no host, no awkwardness! Just a rooftop bar at sundown, cocktails in hand and a DJ spinning your favourites, the twist? EVERYONE'S SINGLE!

Take your time, talk to everyone, mingle with the singles overlooking the centre of Wellington's nightlife heart. If needed there will be conversation prompts on each table for you to spark up a conversation!

description:
Skyline Singles, Sick of swiping? Sick of 5 minute time slots with nothing to say? We've got you covered! Join us at Skyline Singles for a singles mixer like no other!
No time limits, no over enthusiastic hosts, no awkwardness and definitely no cheese! Just a rooftop at sunset, a DJ spinning all the bangers and awesome cocktails flowing. The catch? EVERYONE is single! (Bar staff included
)
Mingle, chat, make new friends or meet the love of your life! There'll be talking points and mini games spread around the venue to get stuck into as well so you'll have no awkward silences!
Find tickets on Eventfinda! Tickets include a welcome drink and canapés throughout the evening!

description:
Soup & Solidarity, Join us for a relaxed, creative evening as craft solidarity books for both Ramallah (our sister city) and Gaza, to show our allyship from here in Aotearoa.
We’ll provide scrapbooking materials, but we encourage you to bring your own treasures. Items like stencils, photos, poems, and Aotearoa-inspired artwork are all welcome.
Join us to highlight shared culture through art, music, hopeful messages, and reflections on solidarity here at home.
This drop-in session continues the spirit of our Nakba Day gathering - connecting, reflecting, and expressing care. Expect warmth, soup, bread, tea, incense, beautiful music, and space to stay until late. This event is open to all ages.

You will be Speed Dating with around 8-10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person. Speed Daters will be split into 2 age groups which will run simultaneously. There will be opportunity to mix with the other group during the break.
Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!
We will have the entire venue for this event.

This is a unique opportunity to meet amazing women, forge new friendships, and discover potential romantic connections in a warm, inclusive, and supportive atmosphere.

description:
Speed Dating for the Neurodivergent, Age groups: 30-42, 43-55

Looking to meet new friends to hang out with, or maybe find love in a comfortable, respectful environment? Join us for a speed dating event designed specifically for autistic adults in Wellington!

This inclusive and sensory-considerate evening is all about meaningful conversations and low-pressure socializing. Whether you’re looking for friendship, romance, or just a fun evening out, this is your chance to connect in a space designed with your needs in mind.

Cost: $39, includes food and first drink

Age groups: 20-35, 35-50

Accessibility and Comfort:
We’re committed to making this event as accessible and welcoming as possible. Sensory-friendly spaces, quiet zones, and fidget-friendly items will be available. There will also be conversation prompts on the table. Let us know any additional accommodations you may need when registering.

Who Can Attend:
All genders and sexualities are welcome to come and mingle and meet others for friendship but the speed dating part of this evening works best for heterosexual people.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Speed Puzzle fundraiser for CanSurvive Dragon Boat Club, Join us for CanSurvive’s very first speed puzzling event!
Each team receives the same 500-piece puzzle and races to complete it as fast as they can.
You can have up to three people in a team and there’s a two-hour time limit.
Our unique puzzle design is top secret and stays covered until the timer starts and you can rip into it! What we can tell you is that we’ve created a beautiful new design in collaboration with New Zealand artist Lori Davis, and it’s been produced by New Zealand’s premium puzzle company, PieceHouse.
The best bit… anyone can join in! Whether you’re a speedy puzzler or prefer to take your time over a cuppa, you won’t regret giving it a go.
So, what are you waiting for? You can puzzle solo or team up with family and friends to meet like-minded puzzlers - and a few dragonboaters! - for a fun afternoon you won’t forget.
As well as the main event, we’ll have bonus puzzles on the go for the super speedy, there’s a kitchen on site for refreshments and there’ll be a raffle and CanSurvive goodies to buy, including our new puzzle - because why share the puzzle that's included with your ticket when every team member could have their own?
label: Community & Culture

description:
Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band, Spring has sprung, the days are getting longer, the rain is falling sideways. Must be about time we had another céilí! Join The Great Beag Céilí Band at St Michael’s Hall in Kelburn for a rousing evening of dancing to foot-stomping celtic tunes. Our Autumn céilí sold out so make sure you get your tickets early!
If you’ve never been to a céilí (or ceilidh) before, fear not - céilí dancing is very easy! No fancy moves or any previous experience required: our caller will explain each dance, and we’ll all walk it through a couple of times before adding the music.
This is social dancing so bring all your friends! No need to bring a specific partner - there’ll be lots of friendly people to dance with.
Discounted online tickets are available on Humanitix until midnight on September 26th: $24 / $16 concession
https://events.humanitix.com/beag-ceili-spring-ceili-2025
Some door sales may be available on the day: $30 / $20 concession (cash only)
—
Doors open 7:30pm
Adults and age 10+ welcome. Under 16s accompanied by an adult.
Light refreshments will be available. We recommend bringing a water bottle to grab a quick drink between dances - hydration is key!
This is an alcohol-free event.
Getting here: St Michael’s Hall is located at 81 Upland Road in Kelburn Village, just behind the church.
There is very limited on-street parking in the village. We recommend public transport: the 4, 18, 21, and 22 buses stop regularly right outside coming up from Te Aro or down from Northland and Karori.
Be safe online: Tickets are only available online from the Humanitix event. Do not buy tickets from other sources such as Facebook comments or resale sites - these are always scams. If you can no longer attend, please contact us via Humanitix, our socials, or email to discuss refunds.
Health notice: Céilí dancing is a great way to meet lots of people. If you are feeling unwell then please stay home and rest this time, we will see you at the next one.
label: Community & Culture

description:
The Epic Life of Kahe Te Rau-o-te-Rangi, Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum is excited to have Miria Pōmare share the beautiful tāonga of her family’s story for Wellington Heritage Festival.

Miria comes from a long line of influential wāhine Māori. Her namesake, Lady Mīria Pōmare (1877-1971), was a community leader who spent much of her life advocating for the benefits of both Māori and Pākeha. In 1918, Lady Mīria was appointed an OBE for her service to the Māori Soldiers’ Fund which was established to help provide soldiers with comfort (food, knitted garments, letters) while they were away from home. Lady Mīria Pōmare’s story is shared in a display in the Attic of Te Waka Huia.

Hear the life story of modern-day Miria’s tupuna and great Rangatira Kahe who was one of five women who signed Te Tiriti in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. Nau mai, haere mai to hear more about this Mana Wāhine and her truly epic life.

description:
Together in Dialogue: Te Tiriti o Waitangi and Pacific Partnerships, Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Pacific style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and effective insights. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from different communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Together in Dialogue?
In Together in Dialogue, you will share meaningful conversations around Te Tiriti o Waitangi and the role and responsibilities of Pasifika as allies. By engaging in deep talanoa, you will explore cultural, historical, and contemporary implications of Te Tiriti o Waitangi and how Pasifika people can strengthen this unique relationship and promote cultural awareness.
This is a 3 hour in-person learning experience.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.

description:
Toi Art Saturdays: Guided Slow Looking (FREE), Take a closer look. Join free, student-led sessions that invite slow looking, reflection, and thoughtful conversation around art.
Going to a gallery can sometimes feel a bit overwhelming with so much to see – on average, people spend less than 30 seconds viewing a work of art!
At these relaxed sessions, local high school students will guide you in slow looking. This is an approach gaining traction around the world that invites us to linger and look closely, letting our responses unfold. You’ll make your own discoveries and create your own meanings, with some discussion and fun along the way.
Each session will begin by looking at Traffic Cop Bay by Bill Hammond, followed by another surprise artwork. No two sessions will be the same!
No booking required. Meet at the session start time on level 5 in the Toi Art galleries – we'll be waiting in the reading space at the top of the main stairs.
SESSION TIMES
- 10.00–11.00am
- 11.00am–12.00pm
- 12.00–1.00pm
- 1.00–2.00pm
- 2.00–3.00pm

description:
Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse, Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse
This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm.

Visit Upper Hutt Blockhouse as part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025.

The Upper Hutt Blockhouse is one of the few remaining buildings associated with the New Zealand Wars, as well as a monument to Pākehā settler anxiety, built in fear of an attack by Māori that never came.

Visit today and you’ll get a sense of the defensive ‘last stand’ mindset. On both floors you’ll find a series of balistraria, tightly angled gun slots through which members of the militia would defend their posts.

Keep an eye out, too, for an exposed panel where you can see the fine gravel that was packed between the exterior weatherboards and inch-thick interior boards to absorb the impact of answering gunfire. Don’t be fooled by the windows – they were added later. Originally, the loop holes you’ll spy on the walls were the only way to see out.

Inside the Blockhouse, there’s an exhibition from Whirinaki Whare Taonga, telling the early story of Upper Hutt and its Blockhouse.

We will have some knowledgeable people available to share stories, answer questions and some light refreshments. Drop in between 11-1pm and stay as long as you like!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $10 - $15
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/visit-the-upper-hutt-blockhouse/


Health & Safety:
Please note as an historic building the Upper Hutt Blockhouse is not suitable for those with accessibility needs.
label: Community & Culture

description:
WCC "Tequila and Salsa night!", WCC "Tequila and Salsa night!"
Hello again bartenders from all walks of life! Brush up on your Tequila knowledge and your Salsa recipes because the next Wellington Cocktail Competition is just around the corner!
As to the theme for this WCC, it is “Tequila and Salsa food pairing” The hero spirit this time around will be a surprise tequila on the night, but I can tell you it will be a reposado. The catch is, you have to pair it with a salsa that you make yourself. There are no limits on the style of cocktail you want this time around, so get creative!
If you would like to participate, get in touch with me or Dan ASAp as we were running low on time to organize this time around.
Minimum 30ml of Tequila must be used in the drink and as always must be the hero spirit of the night.
You will be making two drinks for the judges to try and 5 minutes to make two servings of your cocktail and serve your salsa.
The judges may also be coerced with bribes and favours during your presentation.
The event will be on 28th of September and the competition will start at 6pm.
If you have any questions about the competition, please ask either me or Dan.
The main aim of this cocktail competition is to help those who may not have entered comps before, gain a bit of confidence and experience, or for people who haven’t entered a comp in a while, to shake off those cobwebs.
It also a chance to meet new people and introduce newcomers to the Wellington bar scene. Most of all the idea is to have fun!
Each competitor will have 5 minutes to make and present two servings of their drink.
All Tequila and corn chips for your salsa will be provided, but you will have to source your own ingredients including citrus and sugar syrup. Glassware and ice will be provided, you are more than welcome to bring specialty equipment and ingredients, however you will be marked on how easy your drink is to replicate.
The competition will be judged by a panel of 3 judges. While knowing your stuff is important, brand knowledge is not the key here. This comp is to engage bartenders in a fun comp environment, so drink and personality are just as important.
Competitors will be first come first serve, so message either me or Dan if you want to be entered, there are 10 spots for the night and there will be prizes for the winner.
There will be drink deals on the night, and make sure you bring your friends, workmates, parents ect ect to cheer you on and heckle the other competitors…
See you all there!

We’re a fun, friendly, and supportive Toastmasters group with usually 15–20 people at each meeting! We meet every Monday evening at St Peter’s Anglican Church (211 Willis St, Wellington) in the Garden Room (entrance via Ghuznee Street side, through the lawn).

description:
Wellington - Women’s Day of Action, Wellington - Women’s Day of Action
Women’s Day of Action: Rise Up for Pay Equity

RSVP here: https://www.together.org.nz/wellington_party_for_pay_equity

132 years and one day after women secured the right to vote in Aotearoa, we are gathering again in strength and solidarity.

The Government gutted Pay Equity legislation that would have eased the cost of living and lifted pay of 182,000+ people. Across Aotearoa there will be activations to send a clear message: Pay equity is not optional. Our livelihoods should never be on the political chopping block.

📍 10:00am – Gather at Midland Park
💜 10:30am – Protest march down Lambton Quay to Parliament
🎤 11:00am – Rally at Parliament
🎉 11:30am – (doors open at 11am) Party for Pay Equity – a free, family-friendly celebration with kai, kids’ activities, live music and more! At Wellington Cathedral of St Paul.

Wear: purple, green and white in honour of suffrage

Everyone is welcome – bring your whānau, friends and community 💜💚🤍

His talk will focus on these projects and the research resources he discovered; he will also discuss issues around making information publicly available through social media.

description:
Wellington Heritage Festival - St. Joseph's Pāuatahanui, Hear the stories, with accompanying photos and maps, which bring to life the families who founded this beautiful church 147 years ago.

Brian Murphy, a descendant of the Murphy family who built St. Joseph's church, will lead this talk. A small community of closely-linked families, with many coming from Roscommon in Ireland, established farms at Pāuatahanui and donated funds to build this timber Victorian-Gothic church.

Brian will relate stories which lie behind the graves and unique windows of St. Joseph's.

Koha entry.

description:
Welly Green Thinks - Spring Edition, Although architecture is a confluence of styles, cultures, amenity, and technical delivery, it is the ‘site’ which buildings are most vehemently shaped by, and yet the land they are located on often loses touch with critical pathways to solving systemic sustainability issues. Tina will discuss this proposition, her observations in practice and what decisions get prioritised, and how we can be more conscientious about land use.  

Tina Williams is a NZ registered architect and current chair of Te Kahui Whaihanga – NZ Institute of Architects Wellington Branch, and has worked on numerous residential and community projects.
Be part of the conversation that aims to shape sustainable and resilient futures for our communities.

We can’t wait to see you there!

description:
Whenua Tapu Crematorium Open Day, Whenua Tapu Crematorium Open Day
Built in 1982, Whenua Tapu Crematorium is a beautiful facility that has served thousands of families.

Hear about the history of the chapel and what it’s like to operate a crematorium from the staff that operate it. You can also do a walk-through of the crematorium (optional).

Cremation is the common choice is NZ when it comes to death, with over 70% of Kiwis choosing it. Traditionally Māori and Pacifica families always chose burial, however there is a slow change happening in that space also. We are passionate about de mystifying what cremation is so families can feel informed about the choices they make.

Come along as we open Whenua Tapu Crematorium to the public and answer any questions you may have.


Cost: Free
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/whenua-tapu-crematorium-open-day/


Health & Safety:
Fire alarms on site, first aid kit on site. Staff will act as wardens in emergency.

Plenty of parking on site and toilets on site too.
