description:
You Should Be Dancing, You Should Be Dancing is back!

A disco dancing celebration. A boogie wonderland featuring classic tunes groovy enough to make even a statue move. A club night of super danceable disco hits!

If you love disco, or just want to shake your thing and have a great time, this night is for you.

All kinds of nice people are welcome. Dress up or down. Good times will be had on the grooviest dance floor with the most glamorous tunes and the greatest vibe. What have you got to lose?!

If you’re into...Earth, Wind & Fire, The Bee Gees, ABBA, Diana Ross, Cher, Boney M, Donna Summer, Kool and the Gang, Chic, Gloria Gaynor, KC & The Sunshine Band, The Trammps, Sylvester, Sister Sledge, The Nolans, The Jackson 5, Shalamar, Womack & Womack, Ottawan, The Village People, Chaka Khan, Evelyn Champagne King, Patrice Rushen, Silver Convention, Divine, Pointer Sisters, Bohannon, Patrick Cowley, Patrick Hernandez, Eruption, Rose Royce, Giorgio Moroder, Evelyn Thomas, Gwen Guthrie, Anita Ward, The Weather Girls, The Whispers, The O’ Jays, The Brothers Johnson, Candi Staton, Amanda Lear, and more more more...you will love this night.

You Should Be Dancing has a love of disco and dancing. We take great pleasure in getting together with friends, playing the best tunes, forgetting about work for a while and grooving the night away. We love to party and we pull out all the stops to keep the dance floor moving to the music. These events are always outrageous fun, so why not come down and get into it.

description:
Manu Park Site Viewing, Manu Park Site Viewing
Meet us and find out how you can build your dream home in a new subdivision that combines outstanding natural beauty and a real sense of community.
The agent is on-site at the end of Karuhiruhi Street every Sunday between 10.00am - 11.00am.
Since its establishment in 2018, Manu Park has become a highly sought-after community, with Stages One and Two fully sold out. Don’t miss your chance to secure a piece of this paradise in Stage 3, where only 8 sections remain.
Manu Park isn’t just a place to live—it’s a place to belong. Designed with families in mind, it offers a safe and welcoming environment where kids can ride their bikes down quiet streets, explore nature on their doorstep, and grow up knowing their neighbours. Centrally located near Waikanae township it offers expansive open spaces and a strong sense of community; Manu Park is a neighbourhood where friendships flourish and families thrive.
Nestled within protected native bush, Manu Park offers breathtaking surroundings, generously sized sections, and the opportunity to build a home tailored to your vision and lifestyle. Named after the Māori word for bird, it sits beside the renowned Nga Manu Nature Reserve, close to Waikanae’s excellent schools and amenities, just minutes from the beach, and under an hour from Wellington city.
Teaming up with local building companies, Manu Park offers House and Land packages for a seamless home-building experience. Visit Manu Park to explore Design and Build opportunities to create a home that perfectly fits your lifestyle.
Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a vibrant community where nature and modern living come together. Visit manupark.nz to learn more and secure your section today
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
October Just Sew, Join us for our Just Sew - October edition!
Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life and learn new skills along the way.
Book below and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.
Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.
These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Our Beloved Indigenous Vegetation - Guided Walk, In this approximately one-hour downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on several native plants from the ubiquitous, such as our well-known cabbage tree, kōwhai and podocarps, to lesser-knowns such as shrubby toroaro/mingimingi, Bartlett's rātā, Three Kings kaikōmako and Three Kings vine/akapukaea. We will also discuss the phenomenon of species radiation exemplified by Hebe and Kauri.
Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.
This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we are delighted and look forward to a day of planting, learning, connecting and creating at the Ruamahanga farm.
Three kilometers west of Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are restoring an oxbow wetland and the riperian edge of the Ruamanhanga river.
Our hosts: Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will be demontrating to us how this restoration work provides a platform for Te Reo o te Wai, and how the arts and conservation programme for local primary children is filling a need for experiential learning.
Children and young people learn about ecology, practice hands-on conservation and find their own ways to ceatively expressing what it means for them to connect to special places withing the Wairarapa Moana.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10:30 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10:30 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses. Free registration opens soon

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (weed-busting fun)
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion, Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion
Step into the colourful, buzzing world of pollination! Join the Wellington Gardens Education Team for a day of hands-on fun exploring how plants and pollinators work together to keep nature thriving.

In the Discovery Garden:
Meet the Beekeepers – Learn how bees keep the hive running, why they’re super pollinators, and try on real beekeeper gear

Sensory Pollination Play Station – Transfer “pollen” between flowers in a fun sensory tray

Outdoor Pollinator Bingo Trail – Explore the gardens to spot different pollinators

Wind Pollination Station – Make mini fans and paper “pollen” to see how the wind carries pollen from one plant to another

In the Treehouse:
🍯 Pollination tastings – Sample honey, olive oil, and chocolate. Delicious local products made possible by pollinators.

Bring the whānau, follow the buzz, and leave with a new appreciation for the small creatures (and breezes!) that make big things happen.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
6-12 In person PLD, The story of Communication and Signs is one of the five great stories which scaffold the learning in Montessori classrooms for the 6-12 year old child. It traces the beginnings of human communication and the development of writing.
How can we as educators encourage writing in our Montessori environments and ensure collaborations and an understanding of the basic writing processes, bring success and enthusiasm to the telling of powerful stories?
What are some of the stumbling blocks for children when researching? How can we provide strategies and structure to enable lively and informative information writing?
In this day-long face to face workshop, with a focus on guidance for narrative and information writing, participants will be invited into the world of learning to write. Strategies and exercises to stimulate interest and action for writers will be given, alongside challenges and advanced crafting lessons for more fluent writers in 6-9 and 9-12 classrooms. We will examine elements of structuring, elaboration, character and place, revision, and author techniques. Note taking and writing for research will be included in an information writing session.
Day 2: Sunday 14th September
Come prepared to share your collective wisdom while we align NZC History curriculum to what we do in our classrooms to ensure that everything is covered. By September we will also have a better idea of where the conventional system is headed with the new-look maths coming out. We will spend time unpacking the the WHY we do what we do.
This is an opportunity for you to discuss, share ideas and gain ideas for ways forward.
label: Education & Learning

description:
Botanical Oddities - Guided Walk, In this one-hour walk will we will see a plant that can’t decide whether it’s a lily or an asparagus, tree trunks that are not really tree trunks, plants that photosynthesise only at night, and a deadly poisonous plant that yields potent cancer-fighting drugs. And discover more on this relaxing downhill amble.

Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn

description:
Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami, In lecture theatre 2 (GBLT2) in the Law School at Victoria University / Te Herenga Waka.
Ramsey Library presents a public lecture by Bradford Haami.
What happens when vastly different ways of being meet? Dame Anne Salmond writes of ‘competing cosmologies’ and ‘ontological collisions’ — European missionaries arriving in Aotearoa in the early 19th century brought a Biblical cosmology that began such a collision. In this public lecture Bradford Haami will explore the interactions between Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual worldviews that continue to evolve up to the present.
* How do Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual beliefs and thought relate?
* How 19th century rangatira negotiate between traditional beliefs and the Biblical narratives?
* Where do Christian and Māori ways of knowing and seeing clash, compete or enrich each other?
* What does being Māori and Christian look like today?

Bradford Haami (Ngāti Awa) is a Māori historian, researcher and author with research interests in Māori worldviews, spirituality, Christianity and cultural preservation. He is Pou Amorangi (Māori Director) at Laidlaw College in Auckland, New Zealand, where he lectures in biculturalism and sits on the governing board of the college. Haami has written several books on Māori history, culture and spirituality, with recent works including Urban Māori: The Second Great Migration (Oratia Media 2018) and Bringing Culture into Care (Huia 2019). He was the Māori curator/expert on the acclaimed Te Taiao / Nature exhibition at Te Papa Tongarewa Museum.
--
To browse the Ramsey Library catalogue, and sign up to borrow books (free), go to https://library.chaplaincyvuw.org.nz

description:
Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!, Wednesday 24 September 2025, 10am – 2pm
Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden
Free

These September school holidays, welcome the season of new life and bright colours at our family-friendly Pavilion Open Day. Tamariki can explore the garden’s spring magic through self-guided, hands-on activities designed to spark curiosity and connection.

Activities include:
- Nature’s Colours Art Table – Create your own “spring colour” bookmark using petals, leaves, and other natural treasures.
- Spring Scavenger Hunt – Follow clues to spot signs of the season: sweet-scented flowers, fresh buds, busy birds and more.
- Spring Reading Nook – Relax on the grass mat with tree-stump cushions and enjoy a basket of spring-themed books.
- Bird’s Nest Discovery Table – Get up close to real nests (ethically sourced), soft bird puppets, and natural playdough to shape “eggs” and match them to their native bird owners.

Perfect for children aged 4–12 and their whānau. Dress for a day outdoors and celebrate te kōanga—the vibrant season of growth!

We’ll see you soon in the Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden!

description:
Pottery for Tweens & Teens - Creative Arts Holiday Programme, Join us for this fun and relaxing two hour pottery where you'll handcraft your own garden orb from clay with experienced ceramicist, Christine Winbush. You will have the option of creating your orb into a hanging planter or a unique decoration for your room or garden. Teens will learn basic hand-building techniques to create with clay.

The pieces will be decorated with underglaze and fired. All art will be ready for pickup approximately 3 weeks later depending on drying times.

Recommended age for this workshop is tweens & teens ages 10 and above.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

description:
Pottery for Tweens & Teens, This course introduces a range of hand-building techniques for pottery/ceramics and is appropriate for teens ages 11-16.

In this course you will learn to:

- prepare clay for use
- learn slab, pinch pot and coil construction techniques
- learn how to glaze your creations
- learn techniques to create art that will withstand the firing process.

Creations will be fired at the end of each term and ready to collect at the beginning of next.

Mondays after school, 13 October - 8 December (no class on Labour Day, 27 October), 3:45 pm - 5:15 pm.

Tamariki will be excited to come home and share their new understanding of how science can be found in our everyday lives, even our kitchens!
Workshops include a complimentary planetarium show.

description:
Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight, Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight
Family tramping.

Take a Kid Tramping Trip for our kids with extra stamina and ability to carry an overnight pack, this one has a lot of climbing. We will head up the translator track from North Egmont, turn off and follow the ridge down to the hut. The next day we will return via the Makatawa track down through the bush and across a few streams.

All participants must be equipped for tramping in alpine conditions. Overnight tramping equipment required.

Children must be accompanied by a parent or caregiver approved by their guardian.
Shared transport costs apply, unless own transport is provided.
$10 per adult passenger, kids or own car free + hut fee.
Hut Tickets or annual pass required.

If interested, please register by Thursday 11 September:
Jo-anne Mowat |

description:
The Pantoloons Present: Cinderella, The Pantoloons Present: Cinderella
Glass slippers, royal balls, and a Fairy Godmother who’s still on her learner’s licence, what could possibly go wrong?

Prince Percy is hopelessly charming (emphasis on hopeless), the Queen is busy approving new royal wave techniques (it’s very hard work being a Queen!), the step-sisters are causing chaos in couture, and Buttons has big dreams!

Will true friendship win over fairy-tale romance? Will Buttons dreams come true? And who is behind the kingdom’s mysterious gossip vlog? Packed with music, mischief, and magical mayhem, this is Cinderella with a twist, a tune, and a whole lot of sparkle! Step into a spellbinding world of wonder where dreams shimmer, magic floats on the breeze, and anything is possible… but only until the clock strikes twelve!

REVIEWS FOR RED RIDING HOOD

“You guys were amazing, thank you so much. Me and the kids had an amazing time. We can’t wait for the next holidays t come see you again.”

“My kids had a blast! My little man was in hysterics at Mr Moa.”

“Love everything that you do and each time gets better and better.”

And don’t miss the FREE face painting (10am-12pm) – what or who could you become!?
Free, drop-in. Limited capacity, first come first served!
Access information: The New Zealand Portrait Gallery is an accessible venue, all on one level. There is an accessible wharepaku (toilet) at the back of the venue. The gallery has automatic sliding doors and glass doors that can be pushed or pulled to enter. We have a wheelchair available for use within the gallery, and there is low stool seating throughout. You can find more accessibility information here. If you have any questions regarding accessibility or if there is something we could do to make your visit easier, please get in touch.

description:
Christmas on the Coast, Christmas on the Coast
Get ready to sparkle, Christmas on the Coast is back! Register now to be a float or stall for the 2025 Christmas Parade - www.kapiticoast.govt.nz/do-it-online/forms/register-your-float-or-stall-for-the-2025-christmas-parade/

Join us on Saturday 13 December, from 11am–3pm at Mazengarb Reserve for a festive family day filled with cheer.

At 11 am, catch the colourful Christmas float parade as it travels from Paraparaumu College along Mazengarb Road to the reserve, then stay on for an afternoon of festival fun.

Enjoy free activities like games, face-painting, live entertainment, a bounce zone, and visits to Santa’s grotto. Bring a picnic or grab a bite from one of our food trucks, and don’t forget to bring a can for the Kāpiti Foodbank collection.

For more info, visit www.kapiticoast.govt.nz/Christmas

description:
Crash Bandihoot & DJ Danger, Yes!!

Welly party favourites Crash Bandihoot return to Petone for another epic Jazz Festival party! Last year tickets sold out and the vibe was awesome!

Crash Bandihoot are a colourful raucous New Orleans street style party brass band known for bringing the weekend carnival vibes. Expect soaring horns and driving grooves and rhythms from the group representing Aotearoa NZ in both Australia and Brazil.

Plus support from the amazing DJ Danger spinning an all vinyl set!

Reviews of Crash Bandihoot -

A plague - Destiny Church

You guys are NUTS. BEST GIG. EVER!! - 5Tapped

See you there!

DJ Danger - 7pm
Crash Bandihoot - 8pm

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!
Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.
Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.
Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.
The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.
Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.
Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!
The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.
Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!
Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free
For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/

description:
Free Status - Free Live Music Wednesdays (Jazz Fest), Lift your midweek with Moon's Free Live Music Wednesday's! Your weekly escape to into the sonic stratosphere
Every week, we feature a rotating lineup of incredible local musicians
Come by early for our $15 pizza specials, served hot 5.30-9pm
Perfect for date night, catch-ups, or just floating solo through the sound waves. Wednesdays at Moon are the place to orbit
This week we have a Jazz Fest special featuring Free Status!
Free Status is a jazz fusion band blending the melodic richness of Herbie Hancock and 70s jazz-funk with an electronic edge inspired by Moby. Their sound is both nostalgic and forward-looking, offering high-energy grooves and inventive compositions.
At the helm is Tommy David (keys), a rising talent whose original works have earned competition recognition and seen him share stages with acts like Dire Straits Legacy Band, Nazareth, and Hello Sailor. Joining him are seasoned rhythm players Behzad Karakia (drums) and Tyler Diprose (bass), both respected for their work alongside Aotearoa’s jazz greats.
The frontline features James Dawes (alto sax), fresh from selection for an international touring ensemble, and Sam Voyle (keys/sax), a longtime collaborator of Tommy’s with standout performances at the America’s Cup and major festivals.
Together, Free Status delivers a vibrant, genre-bending live experience you won’t forget.
Follow Free Status: https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=61575737812566
label: Festivals

description:
GARDEN RAVE, The Garage x Jungle Juice: Wellington

Two worlds, one night.

Born in Auckland, The Garage has become one of the most recognised names in the local techno scene, creating parties that blend high-level production with an authentic underground sound.
In Wellington, Jungle Juice has built a vibrant community where everyone feels like family, connected through music, colour and the energy of every gathering.
Now, both forces come together to bring you a truly unique experience.

Location: The Garden Hotel, 63 Courtenay Place, Wellington

On the dancefloor, feel dark, driving beats and unstoppable energy. In the garden zone, enjoy a vibrant and glowing atmosphere filled with colour, lights and nature.

The Lineup (A-Z)
Andretg
DJ By Accident
Malware
Vness


The Garage and Jungle Juice unite to deliver an unforgettable techno celebration in the heart of the capital. Secure your ticket now on Humanitix and be part of this special night.


*** Important Information ***
This event is R18. Valid photo ID will be required for entry.
Respect each other and the venue.
We will not tolerate any form of discrimination.
Look out for each other and please report any antisocial behaviour.
Consent is key – always.
Lighting & Visual Effects: Please be aware that strobe lights, lasers and other flashing visuals may be in use throughout the night. These effects may not be suitable for everyone.
Photos & Video: Our crew will be capturing the energy of the night through photos and videos. By being here, you’re part of that magic and may appear in content we share to celebrate and promote future events.
Have fun and please find the crew if you have any issues.

Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.

description:
Great Sounds Great festival 2025, Eyegum Music Collective presents GREAT SOUNDS GREAT, a multi-venue music and arts festival taking over Pōneke's Cuba Street precinct for one night only on Saturday 6 September 2025. Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.
Eyegum has worked hard to curate a programme that is sure to offer something for everyone, from first time gig-goers to seasoned live music obsessives. The eclectic lineup includes perennial indie maestros The Bats, capital hometown heroes The Phoenix Foundation, hip hop superstar JessB, troubadour-turned-party starter Anthonie Tonnon, captivating genre-bender Reb Fountain, the incredible local-by-way-of-Naarm Jen Cloher, plus a selection of up-and-coming artists handpicked from Eyegum's Free Wednesday weekly showcase series, and everything in between. There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.
Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. This means more artists and music to experience in a variety of special and unique spaces throughout the night.
Ticket holders will receive a wristband that will give them access to each of the participating venues throughout the event. Information on how to pick up wristbands will be provided to ticket holders closer to the time.
Tickets are on sale now at eyegum.co.nz/great-sounds-great

Where: San Fran, Meow, Valhalla, Rogue & Vagabond, Bedlam & Squalor, Hotel Bristol (2 stages), St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records, 13 Garrett St, and more

description:
Grompage 25', Get Lost Cycling are excited to announce the 3rd edition of GROMPAGE™, Wellington's premier mountain bike movie festival
An opportunity to showcase some of NZ's up-and-coming talent, both in front of and behind the lens!
Entry is free and the opportunity to walk away with glory is priceless. An independent jury will be awarding prizes for "best riding" and "most creative edit" and we'll be running a "people's choice" award as well. Prizes will be announced on the night
Everyone is welcome to come and watch on the night, doors will be open from 6.15pm and movies will be showing from 6.30. All winners will be announced on the night.
Keen to enter? Please send a registration email to info@getlostcycling.co.nz with your team details. Entries close Thursday the 25th of September at 10pm.
Can't make it on the night? Don't worry, all movies will be available to watch online the following week

description:
Heritage Festival Open Days, Heritage Festival Open Days
Join us for an open day in the bell tower of Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, where you can uncover its unique history and see the bellringers come out to play.

Take a tour through our ringing chamber and belfry, and see our 140-year-old bells up close. You will have a chance to watch the ringers in action, and maybe even have a go at chiming our 1500kg tenor bell, the largest swinging bell in New Zealand! Discover the secret world of bells and bellringing, something the public doesn't normally get to see. You may have never known that people are pulling on the ropes to make the bells ring! *One of the few towers in the world accessible by lift!

**Entry by donation**

Health & Safety
Please be aware that touching the bell ropes and access to the bells outside of the designated viewing areas is strictly prohibited. You will only be permitted to handle a bell rope under the guidance and supervision of a bellringer. Hearing protection is not required in the ringing chamber, but earmuffs will be provided whilst in the belfry viewing gallery if the bells are going to be rung.

Location
James Thomas Bell Tower, Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, 2 Hill Street, Thorndon 6011

Irish Cultural Festival, Welcome to the Irish Cultural Festival! Join us at Brewtown Upper Hutt for an afternoon filled with Irish music, dance, food, and fun. Immerse yourself in the rich traditions of Ireland as you enjoy live performances from amazing musicians and dancers. Watch a demonstration of hurling and gaelic football - and have a go using a hurl. Get moving by joining in a ceili. Talk to geneolgy groups about tracing your heritage.

description:
Kaiwhakaataata Māra | Garden Performers, Keep your eyes and ears open for pop-up performances scattered across two of Wellington’s most beautiful gardens. Talented artists will appear spontaneously as you wander through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and the Botanic Garden ki Paekākā, bringing music, storytelling, and theatre to life in unexpected places for Te Wā o te Kōanga, Spring Festival 2025.

Botanic Garden ki Paekākā - Love Birds
Brought to you by the Shakespeare Globe Centre New Zealand
Join us at Puriri Lawn for interactive readings celebrating Shakespeare and spring at 11:30am and 2:30pm, with roaming performers delighting visitors in between.
Come dressed to impress for our bird costume competition, with judging at 12pm and 3pm following the readings. Feathers, colours, and creativity encouraged!

Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush - Meet the Moa
With String Bean Puppets
Come meet Nunu, the friendly moa puppet! Nunu will be roaming the garden during two special sessions: 11:00–11:45am and 12:15–1:00pm. Feed him some leaves, give him a cuddle, and enjoy this fun, interactive experience bringing Wellington’s prehistoric past to life.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
LAUNCHING Season 7 of Seeds to Feeds!, It’s time to prepare for the spring and summer ahead, join us for a meal of celebration and of planning.
We’ll share a delicious celebration meal, made with fresh, locally sourced produce, showcasing dishes that we hope will inspire menus for future harvest Celebrations.
We’ll gather together at 6 pm and spend some time getting connected and inspired.
Dinner will be served at 6.50 pm
After dinner, we will see if we can draw up some ideas, brainstorm resources and garden plans and then look at what your Harvest Festival event might be in March.
We will finish with cake (our favourite) and information on what the next steps will be.
If you are still not sure what Seeds to Feeds is all about, come join us. This is a great way to find out what will be happening in your area and how you can be involved.
RSVP’s essential so we know who we are cooking for x

description:
NZ Brewers Fest, NZ Brewers Fest
NZ Brewers Fest is moving to April!
Lining up with Fresh Hop season, we will be bringing the all the incredible beers, outstanding entertainment and delicious kai you expect, with a fresh hop twist!

Save the date and watch this space for more info, coming soon!


Drinks!
It wouldn’t be NZBF without great beer, and this year 20 of Aotearoa’s best breweries will descend on Brewtown to pour every style you could possibly desire, from crisp Lagers, cold IPAs and hoppy Pale Ales, to funky Sours, smoky Porters, rich Pastry Stouts – and everything in between!

Visit Brewtown’s own custom Unimog Bar for 13 beers handpicked by our craft beer experts, but get in quick – we only have 1 keg of each, and they won’t last long!

New for this year! Step into our cocktail bar for some seriously scrumptious spirits! Our mixologists have been hard at work creating some delicious drops just for you.

We’re bringing in some of the best wines the Wairarapa has to offer, so whether you prefer a crisp Sauv, a fruity Pinot or a refreshing Frosé there will be something to enjoy.

Still not enough for you? Then head down to the Everything Else Bar, for NZ crafted ciders, as well as bourbon, rum, gin and vodka alongside a range of low and no alcohol beers, cocktails and soft drinks.

Kai!
The NZBF food court hosts the region’s top foodies, bringing you big, bold, flavour-packed festival eats that’ll satisfy every craving.
Watch this space as we announce our festive foodie lineup!

Entertainment!
Lose yourself in a cabaret of the bizarre, where the performances are as dark as they are dazzling.

Witness the brutal thrill of buhurt armoured combat, as warriors face off in full medieval kit in a raw display of might and mayhem.

Dance the day away at the main stage, as Welly’s top talent smash out tune after tune, all building up to a headline show from Brewtown favourites, The Blueprint.

Grab your mates and get stuck in at the Games Zone, where a bit of friendly rivalry meets festive fun, and the loser buys the next round.

With affordable return coaches from Welly and Petone and great discounts for group tickets it's scarily easy to get involved!
🎃 R18

description:
POP Go the Festival Singers: Otaki Waikanae Presbyterian Church, The Festival Singers invite you to a enjoy unforgettable music in POP go the Festival Singers – a dazzling celebration of popular songs from the 1920s right through to today. Expect energy, variety, and entertainment as we journey through swing, rock ’n’ roll, Motown, disco, soft rock, and contemporary pop.
The programme sparkles with classics and favourites: a Beach Boys Medley full of surfside sunshine, Ruru Karaitiana’s iconic Blue Smoke, Elvis Presley’s Hound Dog, and Bobby Darin’s Beyond the Sea. We’ll groove with Pharrell Williams’ Happy, cheer to Survivor’s Eye of the Tiger, and celebrate Kiwi pride in Crowded House’s Weather with You. Heartfelt beauty shines through Simon and Garfunkel’s Bridge Over Troubled Water and Billy Joel’s And So It Goes, while fun abounds with The Lion Sleeps Tonight and Gershwin’s sultry Summertime.
Swing makes its mark with Glenn Miller’s Chattanooga Choo Choo and In the Mood, while a rousing Queen Medley and an exuberant ABBA Medley bring the concert to a thrilling close. Along the way, enjoy contemporary sparkle with Dua Lipa’s Levitating and the timeless artistry of these unforgettable hits.
With the incomparable Jonathan Berkahn at the piano, every piece shines with character and style. This concert promises nostalgia, joy, and toe-tapping fun – a true trip down memory lane with something for everyone.
Join us and be part of a celebration of music that entertains, connects, and uplifts.
label: Festivals

description:
Paekākāriki Pride Parade, Dress in your brightest colours, bring musical instruments, your dog, your friends and whanau and make some noise for the world-famous-in-Paekākāriki Pride Parade!
Assemble at 2.30pm on the sports field at Campbell Park on The Parade.

The Parade leaves Campbell Park at 3pm sharp. We'll finish up at the usual destination of St Peter's Village Hall where we'll cut the ribbon, walk across the crossing and declare it the World's Shortest Pride Parade, and celebrate eight years of Pride in the friendliest little village in the world.

Show your pride, solidarity, respect and love for and with your rainbow whanau.

description:
Rathkeale Christmas Fete 2025, Welcome to the Rathkeale Christmas Fête 2025! Walk through the gates of Rathkeale College on 1st November and be welcomed by a diverse range of colourful stalls, the aroma of freshy cooked food and plenty of festive inspiration.

Now in its 22nd year, the Christmas Fête has become a must-do event on the Wairarapa spring calendar. Stallholders travel from around the North Island to sell their wares and offer Christmas shoppers loads of inspiration. From festive decorations, clothing, arts and crafts, to flowers, toys and plants – there is something for everyone.

Gourmet food is always a highlight at the Fête - think freshly made gourmet burgers, lamb & mint sausages, wraps, curry, salads, and the ever-popular berries & ice-cream - there is always a huge variety of flavours to tempt the taste buds. Devonshire Teas and home baking served in the Rathkeale Homestead rose garden is a time-honoured tradition while refreshing cold drinks can be sipped on as visitors listen to live music performed by students at various times throughout the day. The popular Christmas cake stall features again this year - but visitors are encouraged to get in early as the cakes often sell out by midday.

The beauty of this Fête is that it’s a day out for the whole family. In addition to the 120 plus stalls, there is plenty to entertain the children including facepainting and magic shows throughout the day.

Visitors can also explore the beautiful, expansive grounds of Rathkeale College including the school gardens designed by Alfred Buxton, the Greek Amphitheatre and the 3km eco-trail which weaves through large stands of native trees, including ancient kahikatea.

Eftpos is available, but we strongly recommend that visitors bring cash.

Koha/gold coin entry.
Rathkeale College is a five-minute drive north of Masterton in the Wairarapa.

There are five fun hydration stations dotted around the course, with water and fruit as well as live music and samples of local wines for those with a more relaxed approach to the day!

description:
Self-guided Tour of Truby King Park, Self-guided Tour of Truby King Park
This Festival event runs from the 18th October to the 9th November 2025.


Discover the hidden history of Truby King Park—scan, stroll, and uncover stories with your smartphone.

Step into a garden full of stories, some inspiring, some surprising. From cherry trees and hospital wards to the people who shaped New Zealand’s early healthcare, follow the QR trail to uncover the layers of Truby King Park’s past.


Cost: Free

Event info here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/self-guided-tour-of-truby-king-park-25/


Health & Safety:
This is a self-guided experience. Please explore within your limits. Wear good shoes and dress for the weather.

Parts of the park may be cordoned off for your safety. Please respect the cordons. Paths and steps may be slippery when wet.

description:
Slow Grind Fever [AUS] - Wellington Jazz Festival, Express from Melbourne, Australia and crossing international waters for the first time this October, Meow is excited to welcome the slowest, spookiest, smokiest and swingin-est club night Wellington has ever seen: 'Slow Grind Fever'.
For this one-night-only episode of SGF Wellington, founder Richie1250 (106.7 PBS FM) will be joined by fellow Melbourne radio alumnus Dr. Popalotacorn (RRR, 98.1FM Raglan) and Wellington's own belle of the airwaves Miss Juliet (RadioActive.FM Americana)
Slow Grind Fever was born in 2012 when Richie1250 hired a Russian Cultural Centre ballroom and threw a slow dance party for his 30th birthday, and it's been running as a regular monthly club night ever since. Richie and his friends play the slowest, sleaziest, spookiest, sweetest, swinginest old records they can find, and people dance real slow in a haze of smoke and dim red light. It's a good time.
In the last few years Richie has taken Slow Grind Fever on the road, with regular dances in Sydney, Hobart, Darwin and Alice Springs. They post up a monthly Slow Grind Fever mix in the week before the party every month, and have collaborated with Stag-O Lee Records in Germany on a series of Slow Grind Fever LPs and CDs.
Enjoy the music and if you feel so inclined, get down to Slow Grind Fever - Wellington at Meow on Friday 17th October.
Listening to the MP3 mixes is nice, but when you’re in the room all
wrapped up in smoke with the music sizzling right off the old records, through the speakers and into your brain, well, there's nothing quite like it…
http://www.slowgrindfever.com/
https://www.instagram.com/slowgrindfeverclub

description:
Te Papa Foundation Gala, Wellington’s premier black-tie fundraising evening, the Te Papa Foundation Gala brings together Aotearoa New Zealand’s leading supporters of arts and culture.

Join us for an inspiring evening in the heart of Aotearoa New Zealand’s much-loved national museum. Feast your eyes and discover new favourites in Toi Art – the home of the National Art Collection. Enjoy handcrafted cocktails, then savour an exquisite three-course dinner paired with premium local wines. Bid on exclusive experiences and luxury items in our live charity auction, thanks to Webb’s. Celebrate the evening with performances from acclaimed local musicians, including Ainslie Allen and Lisa Tomlins.

All proceeds from the event support exhibitions, research, and education programmes, ensuring Te Papa continues to thrive for generations to come.

Can’t make it? Our digital auction will be hosted by Webb’s from 28 August to 10 September. Watch this space for more information and the link.
label: Festivals

description:
Te Papa Foundation Gala, Wellington’s premier fundraising event, the Te Papa Foundation Gala brings together Aotearoa New Zealand’s leading supporters of arts and culture for one spectacular night in the museum.
Enjoy handcrafted cocktails, discover new favourites in the Toi Art galleries, savour an exquisite three-course dinner paired with premium local wines, bid in our live charity auction, and then dance to live performances from acclaimed local musicians.
Thanks to Webb’s, the Gala features a special live auction of once-in-a-lifetime experiences, including Sake & sushi with Dick Frizzell, a stunning carving by Tim Steel (Ngāi Tahu), and luxury escapes.
Tickets cost $3,000 for a table of ten, or $300 per person.
All proceeds from the Gala supports Te Papa’s work across art, culture, history, science, and nature, ensuring that our much-loved national museum continues to thrive for generations to come.
Can’t make it? Our digital auction will be hosted by Webb’s from 28 August until 10 September. More information at tepapa.nz/gala.

description:
Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: Dimebag and Ozzy Memorial Show, Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: Dimebag and Ozzy Memorial Show
Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: A Memorial for Metal Legends
Rail Records, Wildkiwi Distillery, Women's Refuge, and Rockstock present a monumental night of heavy metal in honor of two of the genre's most important and beloved figures: the legendary guitarist "Dimebag" Darrell Abbott of Pantera, and the recently departed Godfather of Metal, Ozzy Osbourne.

Join us on Saturday, December 6th, 2025, at Wildkiwi in Upper Hutt for a memorial show that will shake the foundations. This date holds a special importance to us metal heads, falling just three days after what would have been Ozzy's 77th birthday (December 3rd) and just two days before the anniversary of Dimebag's tragic passing (December 8th, 2004), giving us all a chance to raise a glass and celebrate both legends in the loudest way possible.

This is a night to pay tribute to the artists who defined a generation of heavy music. From Dimebag's revolutionary groove and unmistakable harmonic squeals to Ozzy's haunting vocals and iconic stage presence, their impact is eternal. We invite the metal community to come together for an unforgettable evening of remembrance, unity, and blistering riffs.

The Lineup
Prepare for a full-throttle sonic assault from four of New Zealand's premier tribute acts, performing the anthems that have become the soundtrack to our lives:

•Hell's Wrath delivering the ferocious power of Pantera

•Zombie Stomp (ft. Danny Rascal) channeling the madness of Ozzy Osbourne

•Angel Dust performing the eclectic genius of Faith No More

•Demon Fetal Harvest unleashing the thrash mastery of Megadeth

(More bands to be announced!)

Event Details
•Date: Saturday, December 6, 2025

•Venue: Wildkiwi, Unit 13/27 Blenheim Street, Maidstone, Upper Hutt

•Time: Doors open at 6:00 PM

•Age Restriction: This is a strictly R18 event. ID will be required.

•Charity: We will be accepting donations at the event and at point of sale on behalf of Women's Refuge. Your support is greatly appreciated.

Ticket Information
Secure your spot to witness this massive tribute event. Tickets are on sale now!

•$20 Early Bird (+GST/BF) - Limited quantity available! Grab them before they're gone.

•$30 General Admission (+GST/BF)

•$40 Door Sales/Lates (If not sold out prior)

VIP Table Experience - Only 6 Available!
For the ultimate night out, gather your crew and secure a VIP table.

Price: $240 per table (includes 6 tickets - works out to $40 per person)

Perks:

•Guaranteed reserved seating for your group of 6.

•Early venue access from 4:00 PM to settle in and have a meal.

•10% discount on delicious bar food from the Wildkiwi kitchen.

•First dibs on the merch table.

•Check out soundcheck and meet the bands (where possible).

Limited Edition Merchandise
•Exclusive Event T-Shirt: $30

•Commemorate this special night with a limited edition T-shirt. There are only 20 of these shirts being made, so this is a true collector's item. Available as a ticket add-on. Don't miss out!

This show is a tribute, a memorial, and a celebration. Get your tickets now and be part of a historic night for New Zealand's metal scene.

LINK TO SIZING AND DESIGN HERE:

https://www.railrecords.net/utf2-tee

EVENT TNCS:

https://www.railrecords.net/ticketing-tncs

description:
Wellington Zinefest Weekend 2025, Wellington Zinefest Weekend 2025
Wellington Zinefest is hosting their annual two-day zine festival to celebrate the thriving zine scene here in Te Whanganui-a-Tara.

We're open to the public from 12 til 4 on Saturday October 4 and Sunday October 5 at Te Aro Campus of Victoria University of Wellington Te Herenga Waka - 139 Vivian street.

Each day we'll have sixty+ unique stalls, loaded with self-made zines, comics, prints, and trinkets. Wellington Zinefest markets are free to attend, make sure you bring cash to buy zines tho!

We'll have our beloved community table and trading post running too!

From 11am to 12pm each day we'll run 'accessibility hour'. This is a chance for any visitors who can't attend when Zinefest is crowded. We'll have no music and try to maintain a low-stimulation environment.

description:
Yurt Party 200 Tour!! - Wellington Halloween Show!, Yurt Party 200 Tour!! - Wellington Halloween Show!
Yurt Party are back, fresh out of hibernation and revving up for their biggest Spring tour yet - and a special Halloween show at Meow! (dress up if ya feelin spooky!)

The Ōtautahi crew are hitting the road to celebrate their second album 200, bringing the trademark mash-up of Balkan, Latin and Dub that’s turned backyards, clubs and festivals into full-blown dance floors. There's something about their sound that just makes people lose it in the best way possible.

Honestly, if you haven't experienced the chaos of a Yurt Party show, you're missing out. Pure joy, ridiculous energy, and guaranteed sore legs the next day.

Born in Ōtautahi, Yurt Party have become one of Aotearoa’s most loved festival acts, bringing their fusion of Balkan, Latin and Dub to stages at CubaDupa, Electric Avenue, Twisted Frequency, TSB Festival of Lights and countless clubs and theatres around the country. From street-party beginnings to nationwide tours, their shows are a guaranteed celebration of rhythm and joy.

With support from DJ deetraine ✨

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.
Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.
Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.

description:
Mystery 35mm Movie Marathon, Mystery 35mm Movie Marathon
Surprise we are running a 35mm Mystery Marathon very soon! We have had some exciting news that we cannot share for now but as a result we must move our beautiful 35mm from its usual location into storage for a bit. We are not sure when it will be set back up so to celebrate we are running a marathon of six 35mm features across one Saturday!

We will kick off the first film at 1:30pm sharp on Saturday and will have a short dinner break after the third film. All going to plan we should be done by around 12:30am.

In terms of the features, we have films from the 1960s through to the early 2000s with a mix of comedies, sci-fi, horror and cult classics! Granted not all of these films would be considered masterpieces but there is nothing more fun than sitting in a crowd not knowing what could be coming next!

We will have a snack menu you can pre-order before the first film so aim to arrive around 1:00pm to order. The breaks between films will be very short (probably just enough time for the projectionist to thread up the next film) so make sure you come prepared for back-to-back screenings.

This event has strictly no digital projection, it’s all film all the time. Now in theory it should all playback without a hitch as we are bringing in some of the best projectionist’s Wellington has. But 35mm is a strange beast that can sometimes throw up the odd issue.

All tickets are $50

Seating is general admission and cinema entrance will be determined by earliest ticket purchase times.
label: Film & Media

description:
Seen The Film - Wellington, NZ. A Fundraiser for Te Aro School., We live in an age where, as parents and caregivers, there is more information than ever before. How much screen time is the right amount of screen time for our children? How best can we manage our children's daily meltdowns? Time in, time out, clear boundaries, feel all the feelings - what's best? We are hearing more and more reactive advice on how best to manage our children, yet we are missing the root cause and solution.
SEEN is a groundbreaking feature-length documentary that not only explores the transformative power of personal healing for parents, but also delves into the scientifically supported effects of such healing on parenting and its impact on child brain development.
movie trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bZPQXpw6kT0

Episode 14: "Lonely Souls"  (47mins)
Episode 15: "Drive with a Dead Girl"  (47mins)
Intermission
Episode 16: "ARBITRARY LAW"  (46mins)
With all Log Lady Intros!

(Take the lift or stairs to Level 1 and turn left.)

https://www.teauahaevents.com/our-spaces/cinema

Tickets will be capped/limited so that everyone can have a decent seat; so grab those tickets ASAP and don't miss out on experiencing these truly shocking episodes in a room full of your people that love Twin Peaks!

RULES:
1. Tickets are per person. There will be NO door sales, so DO purchase it beforehand please. 
2. All attendees MUST be 18yo +
3. This is a safe, friendly, INCLUSIVE place. There is ZERO tolerance for discrimination, disrespect or creepy gross behavior of any kind. By attending you agree to the Code of Conduct.
4. Please clean up after yourself if you are snacking and help keep the mini cinema clean as a whistle. 
Thank you! And hope to see you there.

description:
WPF presents: The Hunger (1983), Three of the most beautiful actors to ever live - Catherine Deneuve, David Bowie and Susan Sarandon- star in this ‘80s cult classic about a vampire couple posing as wealthy classical music teachers.
The Hunger is full camp; queer tension and complexity. And beware: the encounters in this movie do not stick to heterosexual norms.
Underworld Tavern in Mt Victoria is hosting this screening in their suitably dark, macabre and industrial surrounds. Prizes will be awarded to the darkest and most vampiric ensemble. A full bar service will be available throughout.
Continuing our run of film fundraisers, The Hunger allows us queers and our allies to engage with a pillar of queer culture. These screenings are organised and hosted by the community for the community. More than just a screening, this will be a queer horror experience.
The event begins at 3pm but come early to get comfortable. The film will start at 3.30. A short comfort break will be provided. Stay for a drink to discuss and dissect.
The Hunger is rated R18. No one under the age of 18 is permitted. Its running length is 97 minutes.
Tickets are $20 waged, $13 unwaged.
ACCESSIBILITY
- Underworld Tavern is fully wheelchair accessible
- The movie will include closed captions

Doors open at 5pm
Film starts at 6pm (running time is 2 hours 4 minutes)
Tickets are just $25 waged / $20 unwaged (all tickets include snacks) and proceeds go toward keeping your Timebank in operation.
About the film:
Award-winning writer/director Miki Magasiva (The Panthers, We Are Still Here) makes his feature debut with Tinā (Samoan for "mother"). Samoan music teacher Mareta (Anapela Polataivao) is plunged into grief after losing her daughter in the Christchurch quakes. Mareta takes a relieving role at an elite private school, where she inspires her students to perform at a big choral competition. In the trailer Mareta faces a condescending interview at Saint Francis, and her growing relationship with "spoiled, rich kids" annoys a family member. Tinā was chosen to open the 2024 Hawai’i International Film Festival.
label: Film & Media

description:

Come along for a movie night supporting a great cause while enjoying this epic film. Set in Belfast, this wild, witty, and politically charged story follows the rise of the real-life rap trio Kneecap, blending music, humour, and rebellion in a way only the Irish can.

Your ticket includes the screening plus a raffle with a twist 😉 - and every dollar goes towards my campaign - it will help me get to the finish line and helping to cover those last few expenses. Imagine the good we can do for our communities if I’m elected!

📅 Date: Monday 8 September
🕖 Time: 5.45pm
Location: Lighthouse Cinema Cuba Street

It’s a perfect chance to laugh and cry - imagine Derry Girls, Trainspotting and Spinal Tap combined - it will change you for the better and help make a difference – so gather your mates and join us for some great craic!

description:
Urban Cocktail Trail I Pōneke Wellington (NZ), On Sale Times
Presale Access - Thursday 31 July, 10am NZST - Register Here
General Access - Thursday 31 July, 12pm NZST
----
Grab your mates and discover the best bars in Pōneke Wellington on the self-guided Urban Cocktail Trail! Whether you're a cocktail lover, or just up for a fun afternoon out, this trail is all about good drinks and great vibes!
Kick things off with a bite at your starting venue, then make your way around using your cocktail vouchers. Where you go and what you sip is totally up to you 🍸
Tickets will fly, so lock yours in and get ready for an afternoon of flavour and fun!
VENUES + SIGNATURE COCKTAILS
🍹Dirty Little Secret Ft. Peachy Pear
Absolut Pear Vodka + Vanilla Galliano + Peach Syrup + Lemon Juice + Egg White
🍹Ernesto's Ft. Pimm'd to the Brim
Pimms + Cucumber Gin + Strawberry Liqueur + Juices
🍹Otto Champagneria & Beer Hall Ft. Saigon Sunset
Papaiti Orchard Gin + Lemongrass Liqueur Syrup + Ginger Syrup + Lime Juice + Soda + Mint
🍹Rosie's Red-Hot Cantina Ft. Coconut Margarita
Cazcabel Coconut Tequila + Triple Sec + Lime Juice + Agave Syrup
🍹St John's Bar Ft. Tiki Trail
Sailor Jerry Spiced Rum + De Kuyper Banana Liqueur + De Kuyper Mango Liqueur + Kwai Feh + Lychee Liqueur + Lemon Juice + Pineapple Juice + Grenadine
🍹The Old Bailey Ft. Pash & Dash
Rum + Passionfruit Liqueur + Passionfruit Syrup + Lime Juice + Lemonade + Mint & Lime Garnish
TICKETS (Limited Availability)
Option #1 – The Connoisseur | $99
$10 Food Voucher for your chosen starting venue (valid until 2 PM)
6x Cocktail Vouchers to enjoy at any participating venue (valid until 5 PM)
Option #2 – The Trailblazer | $75
$10 Food Voucher for your chosen starting venue (valid until 2 PM)
4x Cocktail Vouchers to use at any participating venue (valid until 5 PM)
Note: Food options may vary from the venue’s regular menu due to the event format.
EVENT REGISTRATION & VOUCHER COLLECTION
Pick up your event vouchers and guide at the designated registration point before starting your trail.
Event Day Registration
Location: Ernesto's (1 Grey St, Te Aro)
Date: Saturday 6th September
Time: 12 PM – 1:30 PM
REFUND POLICY
No refunds unless the event is canceled or postponed by the organiser.
GETTING AROUND
The Urban Cocktail Trail is a fully self-guided experience. After checking in at your starting venue, explore at your own pace and choose where to stop along the way.
Click here to visit the Urban Cocktail Trail website
----------
Neighbourhood Events Co. recognises the unique role of Māori as Tangata Whenua and embraces Te Tiriti o Waitangi recognising Māori as Tino rangatiratanga of Aotearoa/New Zealand while embracing the three guiding principles of the Treaty – Partnership, Participation and Protection. We will endeavour to implement bicultural policies and practices that incorporate and value Māori cultural concepts, values and practices.

description:
Urban Wine Walk | Pōneke Wellington (NZ), The streets and laneways of Pōneke Wellington are set to come alive this Spring as a line-up of eight venues each play host to an incredible winemaker, who'll be there ready to pour and chat you through an unforgettable afternoon.

HOW IT WORKS
Kick things off at your chosen starting spot with something to eat, and then let the adventure unfold. Wander at your own pace, glass in hand, discovering incredible wines and venues along the way.
With a stellar line-up of winemakers, good vibes at every stop, and a guaranteed sell-out crowd, the Urban Wine Walk is the ultimate self-guided tasting experience you and your crew won’t want to miss!

PARTICIPATING VENUES & WINEMAKERS
1 - Choice Bros Ft. Coney Wines (NZ)
2 - Glou Glou Ft. Halite (NZ)
3 - Little Beer Quarter Ft. Hopes Grove & Aard (NZ)
4 - Lulu Bar Ft. Margrain Vineyard (NZ)
5 - Noble Rot Ft. VALLI (NZ)
6 - Panhead Tory St Ft. The Good Way (NZ)
7 - The Arborist Rooftop Bar Ft. Matawhero (NZ)
8 - The Tasting Room Ft. Tettonica Wines (NZ)
*Please note that traditional venue menus may vary due to the nature of the event.

TICKETS
Vino Lover Pass – $79 + Booking Fee (Limited Availability)
WHAT’S INCLUDED
Wine Tastings – Up to 3 wines per winemaker along the trail
$10 Food Voucher – Redeem at your nominated starting venue (before 1pm)
$25 Wine Voucher – Put towards event-day wine orders (six-pack minimum, participating producers only)
Event Essentials – Your official wristband & keepsake tasting glass

EVENT REGISTRATION & COLLECTION
Before heading to your nominated starting venue, swing by the official registration point to collect your wristband, tasting glass & vouchers.
Where: Panhead Tory St (1 Tory St)
When: Saturday 18th October | 11am – 1pm
Please note: The Urban Wine Walk officially runs from 12-4pm. Arrive early to grab your event pack and avoid the rush!

REFUND POLICY
Tickets are non-refundable (we’re all in for good times rain, hail or shine!). The only exception is if the event is cancelled or postponed by the organisers – then we’ve got you covered.

GETTING AROUND
One of the best parts about the Urban Wine Walk...? It’s totally self-guided! After checking in at your nominated starting venue, the day is yours! Wander at your own pace, discover new spots and sip your way through the trail however you like.

**Sorry kids, Urban Wine Walk is strictly 18 Years and Over!
label: Food & Drink

description:
We
Mac 'n' Cheese pop-up! Kaibosh X Everybody Eats collab for Welly On A Plate, We
Mac 'n' Cheese! A feast with purpose, where every bowl makes a difference. Celebrate the final day of Visa Wellington On a Plate and the end of winter with the ultimate comfort food: mac 'n' cheese, served all day long.
At just $10 per serve, every bowl will help raise funds for Everybody Eats and Kaibosh - two of Wellington’s legendary food rescue and community dining champions. Help us hit our target of 2,000 bowls in one day!
WHEN: Sunday 31 August, 1-8pm (or sold out)
WHERE: 60 Dixon Street (upstairs)
COST: $10 per bowl (pay-what-you-can options available).
Walk-in only, dine-in or takeaway.
Vegan and Gluten Free options available.
Bring your friends, whānau, or the whole flat!
You'll be able to customise your mac 'n' cheese with a range of toppings and flavours which have been made with rescued food, showcasing just how delicious food recovery can be. From rainbow pickles to herby crunchy crumb, extra #FoodRescue flavour bombs to spice up your mac!
As official charity partners of the Wellington On A Plate Festival, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh turn comfort food into real impact for our communities.
We

description:
2025 Taiwan Update Lectures, 2025 Taiwan Update Lectures
Join us for three talks by experts on different aspects of Taiwan

About this Event

Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.


What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.


Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.

🕑: 01:00 PM - 02:00 PM

description:
Re-imagine Pōneke: Co-design our city, What would Wellington look like if it truly reflected our hopes for a just, sustainable, and thriving city – not in 30 years, but right now?
Join us for Re-imagine Pōneke, a half-day unconference where Wellingtonians will come together to dream big, share ideas, and co-create a bold vision for the future of our city. Through participant-led breakout sessions and live illustration, we’ll collectively map out what a better Wellington could be – from housing and climate action to transport, community spaces, and beyond.
This event is part of Stronger Together, a youth-led campaign making local democracy real and relevant in Pōneke. As local elections approach, it’s time to reimagine how our city works for us all and explore the power of community-driven ideas.
Why come along?
Connect: Meet others who care deeply about the future of our city.
Create: Contribute your vision to a live, visual representation of a better Wellington.
Collaborate: Join participant-driven sessions on issues that matter most to you.
Inspire change: Leave with practical ideas and energy to take forward.
Whether you’re a seasoned organiser, new to local politics, or simply passionate about Wellington’s future, this event is for you.
Tickets: Free and koha-based (pay what you can).

description:
Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order, Abstract
Over the last decade, China has punished countries that undermine its territorial claims and foreign policy goals with measures such as restricting trade, encouraging popular boycotts, and cutting off tourism. These coercive measures have caused significant economic damage to U.S. partners such as Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Australia. This talk focuses on Taiwan’s response to China’s economic sanctions, highlighting the agency of medium-sized countries in the shadow of a great power.
The second part of this presentation will propose a common understanding of the liberal international order in which state and non-state actors follow rules, norms, and legal procedures in conducting international affairs. This rule-based practice is an essential part of the Asian regional order. If Taiwan were integrated into the multilateral institutions in Asia, the chance of conflict would be greatly reduced. The future of Taiwan also depends on the resilience of the liberal international order and other middle-power states in the Asia Pacific.
Bio
Christina Lai is an Associate Research Fellow in the Institute of Political Science at Academia Sinica, Taiwan. Dr. Lai received her Ph.D. in Government from Georgetown University. In 2015-2016, she was a post-doctoral fellow in China and the World Program at Princeton University. She is interested in U.S.-China-Taiwan Relations, Chinese Foreign Policy, East Asian politics, and Qualitative Research Methods. Her works have appeared in the Politics, International Politics, Political Science, PS: Political Science & Politics, Journal of Contemporary China, Pacific Review, and Asian Security.

description:
5-Week Ultimate Calm Forest-Yoga Series, 5-Week Ultimate Calm Forest-Yoga Series
Last class series for 2025. Starts 12 October. Ancient, easy, calm, beautiful and gentle yoga practices to regulate your nervous system and change your internal state. Imagine if you could be calm, anywhere, anytime.

Break the cycle of moving through life stressed, anxious, unsure or unable to deeply recover from illness. We cannot heal when we are stressed - healing only happens when we are relaxed.

This is not strenuous leg-behind-your-head yoga. This beautiful series is guided meditation, gentle stretches, letting every muscle go as you lay over soft bolsters, deep breathing and calming down. These classes return yoga to it's roots - meditation, silent stillness, and experiencing the world without tension.

The impact of each 1.5 hour class will stay with you. And the by the end of the course, you will:

1. Understand more about your stress and relaxation responses
2. Learn easy ways to switch your nervous system over to rest
3. Learn breathing techniques to immediately calm you down
4. Remind your body what is feels like to be at ease
5. Support your mind to naturally and easily take a back seat
6. Learn to better transition to sleep
7. Slow down long enough to listen to what you truly need
8. Have access to audio and video recordings for life
9. Have unlimited support and curiosity throughout the course
10. Create your own home practice after the series.

The world is getting faster. We don't need to. Fast and productive is not not our natural state!

These classes are led by Janie Walker who has experienced chronic stress and long-covid. She teaches from her own experience. You will truly feel supported. You will also crave coming to BeCalmed Studio's little haven in the forest. You can rest here.

Here's what people have said about these BeCalm Yourself classes:

https://www.becalmedstudio.com/.../how-becalm-yourself

Your booking is for all FIVE WEEKLY CLASSES in the series.
Bookings essential.. https://www.becalmedstudio.com/studio-classes

Just 2-3 per class. If this time of week does not suit you, please contact Janie as there may be others wanting a different time slot.

And don't let money be a barrier - we can work something out.

Be calm.

This one-hour talk may bring a few surprises!

Located in the Treehouse Seminar Room, Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.
Free of charge. You’re welcome to bring along your own ‘brown bag’ lunch to enjoy during the talk.

Reg delivers botany lectures for diverse audiences, delving into plant interactions, adaptive radiation, tropisms, and more. description:
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset, Breathwork: A Gentle Reset

Take a pause from the noise of daily life.

This breathwork journey begins with gentle movement to awaken the body and open the breath. Through slow, mindful stretches, we begin softening tension and grounding into the present.

You’ll then be guided through two styles of breathwork — each offering a unique pathway inward. There’s no pressure or expectation, just the freedom to explore what feels right for you:

A dynamic, connected breath for those who wish to build energy, move emotion, or break through internal blockages

A slow, rhythmic breath for those seeking stillness, calm, and deeper grounding

Both approaches invite a sense of spaciousness — physically, mentally, and emotionally — while supporting nervous system balance and inner clarity.

To gently close the session, we’ll move into a quiet, nurturing meditation to support integration and leave you feeling steady, clear, and connected.

Afterwards, stay and enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, lovingly prepared to complement the experience — because healing is also about how we feed and care for ourselves.

Why Breathwork?

Breathwork has helped so many shift from a state of tension and overwhelm into a place of ease, clarity, and resilience — often after just one session. It’s a simple, powerful practice that reconnects you to your body, your breath, and your inner stillness.

You’ll leave feeling more grounded, more present, and more like yourself again.

Meet Karla, your host
Karla is a breathwork and trauma-somatic facilitator based in Aotearoa (New Zealand), originally from Malta. With over a decade of experience in Reiki and three years facilitating trauma-informed, science-based breathwork, Karla combines holistic tools, meditation, and conscious breathing to support nervous system regulation and deep emotional healing. Her offerings help release stored trauma, reduce stress and anxiety, and activate oxytocin—the “love hormone”—fostering connection, vitality, and a sense of wholeness. She currently holds regular classes, workshops, and transformative retreats that nurture the mind, body, and spirit.
label: Health & Wellness

Step out of autopilot and into your own rhythm — this session is about tuning in again.
We begin with gentle movement and mindful stretches to awaken the body, open the breath, and release tension. You’ll then be guided through two complementary styles of breathwork, allowing you to explore what feels most nourishing for you:
A dynamic, flowing breath to energise, release emotion, and move through internal blockages
A slow, steady breath to cultivate stillness, calm, and deeper grounding
Both approaches create a sense of spaciousness — physically, mentally, and emotionally — while supporting nervous system balance and clarity of mind. The session closes with a quiet, nurturing meditation, helping you integrate the experience and leave feeling steady, connected, and present.

description:
Conscious Dance with Janni, I am creating a space to freeform dance – or ‘conscious dance’, where you can nourish your mind, body and spirit through mindful movement.
I’m offering 10 spots (first in) for anyone to come along for free in return for giving some feedback and agreeing to being in some non-intrusive photos to help us plan future events. Details will be provided via email in the next few days.
In this practice, we open and close with gentle, easy movements. You then explore and find your dance flow as we progress into the peak and beyond. The whole experience is yours to create in whatever way, shape or form that feels best for you. It may be fast or slow, wild or contained or alone or with others. You will move and dance to a range of music and there will be minimal guidance from me, as the facilitator.
Dance helps to energise and invigorate us. It has incredible health benefits which will become evident as you get comfortable and curious, build confidence and open your heart and mind to possibility.
If I can't offer a spot on this occasion, I will let you know when our ongoing events commence.

description:
Dance with Janni, Dance with Janni is part free form dance and part relaxation. The ritual of dance promotes creative self-expression, has some great health benefits and is for everyone to enjoy.
This is a safe and inclusive space to move and dance while having the opportunity to relax, stretch and be your true self.
There are no steps to learn, instead there will be minimal guidance to help you during the session.
Bring water, a small blanket, socks or dance barefoot and wear comfy clothes move in. Come as you are and as you feel.
This initiative has the support of Creative Communities NZ.
Koha appreciated.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Dying Matters Week 2025, Dying Matters Week 2025
Paraparaumu Library is hosting two days of events as part of Dying Matters Week 2025 Wellington – Kāpiti, with nine sessions running across 1 and 2 September.

Come along to panel discussions, workshops, and kōrero exploring dying, death, grief, and end-of-life planning.

Dying Matters Week runs in Kāpiti from 1 to 7 September, with other events happening at venues throughout the district.

View the full Kāpiti programme including Kāpiti Crematorium Open time and the Dying Matters Week Expo where you can talk to our Cemetery, Burial & Cremation Advisors online -
https://gowithgrace.nz/dyingmatters/wellington-events/kapiti/
